The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to state agencies and boards. It would be responsible for providing legal counsel to the State Board of Public Accountancy regarding its regulatory authority and the statutory extensions provided by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Holocaust Education Assistance Grant Program within the Maryland State Department of Education to provide grants to local school systems. The grants are intended to support Holocaust education in public schools through teacher training and the acquisition of instructional materials.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE)
qa_results.stakeholders: Local school systems, public school teachers, and Maryland public school students.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Beginning in FY 2027, State general fund expenditures will increase by $50,000 annually due to a mandated appropriation for the grant program. The Maryland State Department of Education can manage the program using existing resources. Local school systems that apply for and receive grants will see an increase in revenues and expenditures for Holocaust education materials and training, with potential grants averaging $2,083 if split equally among Maryland's 24 school systems.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) is the primary implementing agency for the bill, tasked with establishing and administering the Holocaust Education Assistance Grant Program for local school systems.

The Department of Budget and Management (DBM) is responsible for formulating the state's annual budget, which must include the $50,000 mandated appropriation required by this bill starting in FY 2027.
The Governor's Office is responsible for drafting the state’s annual budget and ensuring the mandated appropriation for the grant program is included, as well as signing the legislation into law.
As the state's chief financial officer and paymaster, the Comptroller's office is responsible for the disbursement of the grant funds to the participating local school systems.
The State Treasurer's Office manages the state's banking services and acts as the custodian of the funds that will be appropriated and distributed through the grant program.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the primary legal advisor to MSDE and would likely provide counsel regarding the legal framework and administration of the newly established grant program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the square footage threshold for State real property leases that can be entered into without competitive procurement from 2,500 square feet to 5,000 square feet. It also reduces the mandatory advertising period for State rental needs from 30 days to 20 days and requires that these needs be advertised on the Department of General Services website and the eMaryland Marketplace online procurement system.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of General Services
qa_results.stakeholders: State agencies seeking to rent office space, commercial property owners and landlords, and the public in localities where the State is looking to lease property.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no material impact on State or local finances. While the Department of General Services will adjust its procurement and advertising procedures for real property leases, these changes do not affect overall revenue or expenditure levels.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of General Services (DGS) is the primary agency responsible for managing the state's real estate leases and the eMaryland Marketplace procurement platform. This departmental bill directly alters DGS's procedures for advertising building needs and increases the square footage threshold for noncompetitive leasing, which DGS manages to improve efficiency.

The Board of Public Works is the highest administrative authority for state spending and is statutory required to review and approve state real estate leases. Changes to procurement thresholds and advertising timelines directly affect the flow of contracts and the regulatory framework that the Board oversees for state property management.

The Governor's Office is relevant because the Governor sits as one of the three members of the Board of Public Works, which is responsible for the final review and approval of the real estate leases impacted by the procedural changes in this bill.

The Comptroller of Maryland is a member of the Board of Public Works. In this capacity, the Comptroller acts as a fiscal watchdog and must review and approve significant state expenditures, including the building leases affected by the new thresholds and advertising requirements established by this bill.

The State Treasurer serves on the Board of Public Works, which manages the state's procurement and capital improvements. The Treasurer's Office participates in the approval of the real property leases that are subject to the revised competitive requirements and expedited advertising periods defined in this legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This emergency bill modifies the requirements for scheduling and conducting special elections to fill vacancies in a county council or the office of a county executive. It requires the date of a special election to be at least 90 days after the adoption of a resolution and prohibits scheduling it within 120 days of a regularly scheduled election. The bill also authorizes the State Administrator of Elections to oversee special elections when local and state laws conflict, removes the requirement for mailing specimen ballots in mail-in special elections, increases the timeframe for mailing ballots to voters to 30 days before the election, and allows the use of ballot drop boxes.
qa_results.responsible_party: The State Administrator of Elections and local boards of elections
qa_results.stakeholders: Registered voters in Maryland counties, local boards of elections, and county government officials including county councils and executives.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State finances. Local government finances may be indirectly impacted as the bill's scheduling restrictions may dictate whether special elections are held independently or concurrently with regular elections. For context, a countywide special primary election in Prince George’s County cost approximately 2100000 dollars in 2024, indicating the potential scale of local expenditures for independent special elections. The removal of specimen ballot requirements may provide some cost savings for mail-in special elections at the local level. Any change in the number of independent special elections held would impact local expenditures for staffing and ballot mailing and processing. No revenues are expected to be generated for either the State or local governments as a result of the bill's provisions. State Board of Elections indicates changes are necessary for administrative efficiency and to ensure voters have sufficient time to participate in special elections. Potential impacts are noted to be minimal for small businesses by the Department of Legislative Services and State Board of Elections because the changes relate to governmental administrative and legal protocols for elections rather than private sector activities or regulations affecting commerce and standard business operations in Maryland districts and counties during election cycles or periods of vacancy filling for county leadership roles. The emergency status ensures the bill takes effect immediately upon enactment to address current and upcoming election cycles without delay, potentially affecting special elections scheduled for later in the 2025 calendar year following the governor's approval date in late April of 2025 as indicated in the enacted legislation text provided in the source materials for this analysis of House Bill 75 and its fiscal impact note prepared by the Department of Legislative Services of the Maryland General Assembly for the 2025 legislative session cycle and the subsequent chaptering of the legislation into Maryland law following its passage and signature by the Governor Wes Moore on April 22nd, 2025. This completes the fiscal overview as detailed in the available documentation for the Maryland legislative process and departmental review of election law changes for the current session. No further expenditures or revenues are projected beyond the context provided for local government administrative costs related to special election timing and mail ballot handling procedures updated by the bill's enactment into law as a priority departmental measure requested by the State Board of Elections for administrative clarity and voter participation protection across the state's diverse agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for managing and supervising elections in Maryland, SBE and its local boards are directly impacted by the bill's changes to special election timing, mail-in ballot procedures, and the State Administrator's specific authority to resolve conflicts between county laws and state election regulations.

The OAG serves as the chief legal advisor to state agencies, including the State Board of Elections. They would provide counsel regarding the bill's provision allowing the State Administrator to override county charters when they conflict with state election law.

The Governor's Office oversees all state departments and agencies, including the State Board of Elections. This is a departmental bill from the administration, and the Governor is responsible for signing the legislation and enforcing the altered state election laws.

The OSP investigates and prosecutes violations of state election laws. Changes to the legal requirements for conducting special elections, including timing and ballot distribution mandates, fall under their oversight of electoral integrity.

The OLA conducts compliance audits of the State Board of Elections and local boards; they would be responsible for auditing the fiscal and operational compliance of these boards with the new requirements for special election mailings and drop box administration.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes specific procedures and acceptable methods for an authorized fiduciary to provide notice or send documents when exercising decanting power under the Maryland Trust Decanting Act. It requires notice to be sent via methods likely to result in receipt, such as personal service, certified mail, or courier delivery, while also allowing for alternative methods like email or facsimile if the recipient agrees in writing.
qa_results.responsible_party: Authorized fiduciaries (trustees or other fiduciaries with discretion to distribute trust property)
qa_results.stakeholders: Authorized fiduciaries, qualified beneficiaries of trusts, and other persons entitled to notice under the Maryland Trust Decanting Act.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect State or local government finances. Small business impacts are expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Register of Wills is responsible for overseeing the administrative probate of estates and protecting legal records related to the Estates and Trusts Article of the Maryland Code. This bill directly amends that article by establishing specific notice and transmittal requirements for trust decanting, a topic within their core domain of expertise and records management.

The Administrative Office of the Courts manages the infrastructure of the Maryland Judiciary. Because the Maryland Trust Decanting Act involves fiduciary powers that may be subject to judicial oversight or litigation, the AOC is relevant for ensuring that procedural changes regarding notice and document service are integrated into court education and administrative guidelines.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the state's chief legal advisor and was specifically consulted regarding the fiscal impact of this bill. Its Consumer Protection Division and general legal oversight units may have an interest in the fair notification practices established for authorized fiduciaries.

The Governor's Office is the principal executive agency responsible for signing legislation into law and overseeing the operation of state departments. The Governor officially signed this bill (Chapter 221) on April 22, 2025.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes that each animal harmed in a violation of state animal cruelty laws is considered a separate offense and an individual victim for the purpose of the sentencing guidelines' stacking rule. It further specifies that a conviction for an animal-related crime may not merge with other convictions arising from the same act and that sentences may be served consecutively or concurrently. Additionally, the bill clarifies that certain animal cruelty prohibitions do not apply to legal hunting or fishing activities conducted using humane methods.
qa_results.responsible_party: Judiciary and Maryland State Commission on Criminal Sentencing Policy
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals charged with or convicted of animal-related crimes, Maryland state and local courts, and law enforcement agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have a minimal fiscal impact. State and local revenues may increase slightly due to fines collected from animal cruelty convictions. State and local expenditures may also increase minimally if the new sentencing rules result in longer periods of incarceration or more individuals being committed to correctional facilities.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies the sentencing guidelines 'stacking rule' and establishes that each animal harmed constitutes a separate offense, which judges and court staff must implement during sentencing proceedings.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The prohibition on merging convictions and the requirement to treat each animal as a separate victim for sentencing significantly increases the potential penalties for defendants, directly impacting the agency’s defense strategies and caseload complexity.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's sentencing changes, including the non-merger of offenses and the ability to impose consecutive sentences, are expected to increase the length of stay and the population within state correctional facilities.

The bill creates specific exemptions for hunting and fishing activities that are conducted in compliance with Title 4 and Title 10 of the Natural Resources Article, which the department and its Natural Resources Police oversee.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Commission on Criminal Sentencing Policy (MSCCSP), which manages the sentencing guidelines and stacking rules explicitly modified by this bill, falls under this category of government bodies.
The bill establishes that animal cruelty laws do not apply to customary agricultural husbandry practices or food processing, both of which are regulated by the Maryland Department of Agriculture.

As a primary statewide law enforcement agency, the State Police investigate criminal acts including animal cruelty and will be responsible for charging violations under the new multi-offense framework.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's central hub for public safety policy, this office advises on criminal justice strategies and manages data/funding that would be affected by changes in animal cruelty sentencing and prosecution.
The OAG represents the state in criminal appeals and provides legal counsel to the agencies impacted by the implementation of new animal cruelty exemptions and sentencing rules.
The bill is expected to have a fiscal impact on state expenditures due to potentially longer incarceration periods, which DBM must account for in the executive budget.
As the office that signed the bill into law and oversees the executive agencies responsible for enforcement and corrections, it maintains high-level relevance to the implementation of the policy.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the time period from 90 days to 4 years during which an individual who has held a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration (HVACR) contractor license may apply for license restoration after its expiration by paying a renewal or reinstatement fee. If the restoration application is not made within this 4-year period, the State Board of HVACR Contractors may require the applicant to undergo the full initial application process, including examinations.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Heating, Ventilation, Air-Conditioning, and Refrigeration Contractors
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractors, including master, journeyman, and apprentice licensees.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of Labor's State Board of HVACR Contractors can implement the bill's changes using existing budgeted resources. State revenues and expenditures are not expected to be materially affected. There is no fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Labor is the primary agency impacted as it houses the State Board of Heating, Ventilation, Air-Conditioning, and Refrigeration (HVACR) Contractors, which is directly responsible for administering the licenses and restoration processes modified by this bill.

The Office of the Attorney General acts as the legal advisor to the Department of Labor and its licensing boards, providing guidance on the regulatory and legal changes to licensing restoration timeframes.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for state revenue estimation and fiscal oversight; the bill impacts the State Occupational Mechanical Licensing Boards’ Fund through shifts in renewal and reinstatement fee timelines.
The Office of Administrative Hearings conducts proceedings for the Department of Labor and would adjudicate any contested cases or appeals resulting from license restoration denials or disputes.
The Governor's Office oversees the Department of Labor as an executive agency and is responsible for the final signing of this departmental legislation into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the administrative oversight of Opioid-Associated Disease Prevention and Outreach Programs by transferring the authority to hear appeals and chair the Standing Advisory Committee from the Deputy Secretary for Public Health Services to the Secretary of Health or their designee. The bill also adjusts the membership of the Standing Advisory Committee to reflect organizational changes within the Maryland Department of Health.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Local health departments, community-based organizations, individuals utilizing harm reduction services, and the Standing Advisory Committee on Opioid-Associated Disease Prevention and Outreach Programs.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is technical in nature and has no direct effect on state or local finances. There is no impact on revenues or expenditures for state or local governments, and the economic impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal or non-existent.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health is the primary agency responsible for the administration of Opioid–Associated Disease Prevention and Outreach Programs. The bill modifies the Department's internal appeals process for program authorization and designates the Secretary of Health as the appointing authority and chair for the program's Standing Advisory Committee.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Executive Director of the Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention and Policy is specifically charged by the bill with nominating a representative from law enforcement to serve on the Standing Advisory Committee on Opioid–Associated Disease Prevention and Outreach Programs.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's primary focus is altering the membership, chairing, and statutory procedures of the Standing Advisory Committee on Opioid–Associated Disease Prevention and Outreach Programs, which falls under this functional designation of government bodies.

The Office of the Lieutenant Governor is responsible for leading significant statewide initiatives regarding public safety and coordinating the state’s response to the opioid crisis, making the administrative oversight of these outreach programs highly relevant to their mission.

As the chief executive office, the Governor’s Office oversees all state departments and signs or vetoes legislation affecting executive branch operations, including the organizational structure of the Department of Health and its advisory bodies.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the primary legal advisor for the Department of Health and would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the revised appeals process and the drafting of regulations mandated by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a population-based quota for Class A and Class D (off-sale) alcoholic beverages licenses in Anne Arundel County, limiting issuance to one license per 3,500 individuals in specified tax assessment districts. It also restricts the transfer of these licenses to locations within the same assessment district where they were originally issued or located as of July 1, 2025.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Anne Arundel County
qa_results.stakeholders: Current and prospective alcoholic beverages license holders in Anne Arundel County and residents of the county's tax assessment districts.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no effect on State finances. For Anne Arundel County, there is no impact on expenditures, and revenues are not expected to be affected as existing license renewals and transfers are permitted, even though five of the seven applicable districts currently exceed the population-to-license ratio.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor serves as the chief executive who signs legislation into law and oversees the operations of state boards. The Anne Arundel County Board of License Commissioners, which is the primary body responsible for implementing the license quotas and transfer restrictions in this bill, consists of members appointed by the Governor.

This office is responsible for recruiting and vetting candidates for state boards and commissions, including the Board of License Commissioners for Anne Arundel County, which is tasked with the direct enforcement of the population ratio quotas established by this bill.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to state boards and commissions. As the Anne Arundel County Board of License Commissioners is a state-mandated regulatory body, the OAG would provide legal guidance on the implementation of the new population-based licensing restrictions and handle any related litigation.

The Comptroller is the state's chief fiscal officer and tax collector, responsible for monitoring business licenses and revenues related to alcoholic beverages. While the fiscal note identifies no immediate state fiscal impact, the agency maintains a role in the broader regulatory and fiscal oversight of the industry.

The bill establishes license quotas based on population estimates and specific tax assessment districts. The Department of Planning manages demographic and economic research and provides technical assistance to local governments regarding land use and community planning data.

As the state's economic development agency, Commerce monitors regulations that impact small business growth, competition, and the expansion of the retail sector, including the alcoholic beverages industry in specific counties.

The bill defines assessment districts based on a specific 'Official Map' titled 'Tax Assessment Districts, 2005.' The State Archives is the central depository for official government records and maps of permanent historical and legal value.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of a public entity to include resilience authorities for the purposes of insurance pooling. This enables resilience authorities to join with other public entities to purchase casualty, property, or health insurance or to self-insure against related risks.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Resilience authorities, local governments (counties and municipalities), and public entity insurance pools.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect State government operations or finances. Local expenditures may decrease if the insurance pooling authorized by the bill results in lower premium costs for resilience authorities. Local revenues are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the Insurance Article and alters the definition of public entities permitted to pool insurance or self-insure, a regulatory area overseen by the MIA to ensure compliance and market stability.

Resilience Authorities are established to undertake resilience infrastructure and hazard mitigation projects, which aligns directly with MDEM's mission to build statewide resilience and protect residents from disasters.

Resilience Authorities often focus on climate-related infrastructure and protection against environmental hazards, which are key components of MDE's mission and its lead role in the state's climate change initiatives.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for the State and its agencies, providing essential counsel on the legal implications of altering insurance pooling definitions and the powers of public entities.

The State Treasurer's Office manages the state's insurance and risk management programs; as the state's expert on public fund safeguarding and insurance, it has an interest in the framework for public entity insurance pools.
MDP coordinates sustainable growth and land use policy; Resilience Authorities support infrastructure that is critical to the long-term planning and sustainability of Maryland communities.
This multi-agency initiative coordinates sustainable growth and environmental stewardship efforts across MDE, DNR, and MDP, all of which intersect with the work of local Resilience Authorities.

Resilience infrastructure projects often involve protecting transportation networks (highways, bridges, and ports) from climate impacts, making MDOT a relevant stakeholder in the viability of Resilience Authorities.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies implementing resilience policies and is responsible for signing the bill into law to enable these authorities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill makes significant revisions to the Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Program, primarily by delaying its implementation. It pushes the start date for required contributions from July 1, 2025, to January 1, 2027, and delays benefit payments until a date between January 1, 2027, and January 3, 2028. The bill also introduces an 'anchor date' for benefit calculations, postpones the participation of self-employed individuals until the Department of Labor adopts specific regulations by July 1, 2028, and adjusts various reporting and administrative deadlines.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland employees, employers with 15 or more employees, self-employed individuals, and community health service providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill delays the FAMLI Program's contribution and benefit start dates, resulting in a significant reduction in special fund activity. Special fund revenues decrease by approximately $1.3 billion annually in FY 2026 and FY 2027. Special fund expenditures for benefits decrease by up to $1.8 billion in FY 2027 and $946.7 million in FY 2028. In FY 2026, general fund expenditures increase by $37.3 million for administrative costs (offset by other savings for a net $22.5 million increase) due to the lack of available special fund revenue. Local governments will also realize expenditure savings from delayed employer contributions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Labor is the primary agency responsible for administering the Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) Program. The bill directly revises the department's duties, including the creation of regulations for self-employed enrollment, the setting of contribution rates, and the timeline for benefit payments.

The bill explicitly mandates that the Maryland Department of Health reimburse community providers for their share of FAMLI contributions. The delay in the program causes a significant multi-million dollar reduction in health-related expenditures for fiscal years 2026 and 2027.

The bill effectuates a major shift in the state budget, moving approximately $37.3 million from general funds to replace special fund administrative costs. DBM is responsible for the state personnel system and the fiscal oversight impacted by these billion-dollar fund delays.

The bill directly alters the statutory timeline for the Board of Public Works to perform its duty of determining whether economic conditions allow for the indexing of maximum weekly benefits, delaying this responsibility from 2026 to 2028.

The Comptroller manages the state’s central payroll and will be responsible for implementing FAMLI contribution deductions for over 100,000 state employees. The delay in the program significantly impacts the Comptroller's implementation timeline and revenue tracking duties.

As the custodian of the state's financial assets, the Treasurer manages the investment of the FAMLI Fund. The billion-dollar shifts in revenues and the program's revised fiscal structure directly impact the management of these public funds.

The bill is a departmental initiative from the executive branch that delays a landmark statewide policy. The Governor is responsible for signing the legislation and overseeing the agencies implementing these large-scale administrative revisions.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Labor and will be responsible for providing counsel on the drafting of new regulations for self-employed individuals and ensuring compliance with revised statutory definitions like 'anchor date.'

The bill references the Insurance Article regarding employer insurance pools and restricts the Department of Labor from requiring certain pools to escrow funds. The delay also affects the regulatory environment for private FAMLI insurance plans.

The OLA is responsible for conducting fiscal and performance audits of state agencies. The management of the revised FAMLI fund and the Department of Labor's adherence to new administrative deadlines will be a subject of future audits.

The delay in the FAMLI Program impacts the procurement and development timeline of the complex IT infrastructure required for processing claims and managing employer accounts, which falls under DoIT's strategic oversight.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the purpose and use of the Maryland Farms and Families Fund to allow the Maryland Department of Agriculture to implement the Maryland Farms and Families Program directly or through partnerships with nonprofit organizations and other responsible entities. The program aims to increase the purchasing power of food-insecure residents by matching federal nutrition benefits (SNAP, WIC, and FMNP) at farmers markets and farm stands, while also providing logistical and marketing support to increase the use of these benefits.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture
qa_results.stakeholders: Food-insecure Maryland residents, Maryland farmers, nonprofit farmers markets, and nonprofit organizations involved in food access programs.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State finances, as it primarily redirects the authorized uses of the existing Maryland Farms and Families Fund. The Fund receives a mandated annual appropriation of $300,000, and the Maryland Department of Agriculture can implement the bill's changes using existing resources. There is no impact on local revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Agriculture (MDA) is the primary implementing agency for the Maryland Farms and Families Program. The bill is a departmental request from MDA, and the Secretary of Agriculture is responsible for administering the fund and determining eligibility for participants.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Agricultural & Resource-Based Industry Development Corp.
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: According to the fiscal note, MARBIDCO currently partners with SMADC to administer the program's funds. The bill is intended to streamline management by allowing MDA to manage the program directly, thereby removing the administrative role currently performed by MARBIDCO.

The bill mandates that the Governor include an annual appropriation of $300,000 in the state budget for the Maryland Farms and Families Fund. DBM is the central fiscal authority responsible for overseeing the formulation of the Governor's budget and managing such mandates.

The Governor is responsible for drafting the annual budget, which must include the mandated appropriation for the Fund. Additionally, the Governor oversees all state departments, including Agriculture, and is responsible for signing the bill into law.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to account for the Maryland Farms and Families Fund, which is established as a special, nonlapsing fund.
The bill explicitly requires the State Treasurer to hold the Maryland Farms and Families Fund separately from other state funds.

DHS is the primary provider of SNAP benefits in Maryland. The bill's program aims to double the purchasing power of SNAP benefits for food-insecure residents, directly impacting the population served by DHS.

The Maryland Department of Health provides public health services and coordinates local health efforts. The bill's program impacts WIC benefit recipients by doubling their purchasing power at farmers markets.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill regulates automatic renewal offers for consumer contracts, requiring sellers to clearly disclose renewal terms, provide accessible and easy-to-use cancellation methods, and send advance notices before a renewal or a free trial (lasting more than 14 days) takes effect. Violations are classified as unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act, though the bill does not authorize a private right of action for damages.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General, Consumer Protection Division
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland consumers and businesses that offer automatic renewal subscriptions or purchasing agreements.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no material impact on State or local finances or operations. The Office of the Attorney General's Consumer Protection Division can implement the bill using existing resources. While existing civil penalty provisions under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act apply to violations, they are not expected to significantly affect state revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of the Attorney General (OAG), primarily through its Consumer Protection Division, is the lead agency responsible for enforcing the Maryland Consumer Protection Act (MCPA). This bill classifies violations of the new automatic renewal regulations as unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices under the MCPA, granting the OAG direct oversight and enforcement authority over sellers failing to provide required notices or easy cancellation mechanisms.

The Governor's Office serves as the principal executive agency and is responsible for signing legislation into law and overseeing the operations of state departments. Governor Wes Moore signed this bill, which impacts executive enforcement policy and coordinates with other state agencies excluded from the bill's provisions.

The bill explicitly excludes businesses and individuals with contract renewal practices already subject to regulations, rules, or procedures established by the Maryland Insurance Administration (MIA). This maintains the MIA's independent regulatory jurisdiction over insurance-related subscriptions and policies.

The bill explicitly excludes services regulated by the Maryland Public Service Commission (PSC). This provision ensures that utility companies and other entities under PSC oversight continue to follow commission-specific regulations regarding service agreements and renewals rather than being subject to this broader consumer protection statute.

The Office of Administrative Hearings (OAH) provides an impartial forum for Maryland residents to challenge agency decisions. Since enforcement of this bill falls under the MCPA, administrative proceedings initiated by the OAG (such as cease and desist orders) would be adjudicated by Administrative Law Judges within the OAH.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the Pesticide Applicator’s Law to align with federal standards. It mandates that commercial applications of restricted use pesticides be performed only by certified applicators, eliminating the previous allowance for noncertified individuals to perform these applications under supervision. It also establishes stricter direct supervision and federal compliance requirements for noncertified individuals performing private agricultural applications of restricted use pesticides and repeals obsolete laws regarding cyclodiene termiticides and antifouling paints containing tributyltin.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture
qa_results.stakeholders: Pest control businesses, commercial and public agency pesticide applicators, private (agricultural) applicators, farmers, and registered employees in the pest control industry.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues are projected to increase by at least $140,000 annually starting in FY 2026 as approximately 2,000 registered employees transition to certified applicators, who pay higher annual fees ($100 on average versus $30 for registration). State expenditures are not expected to change because the Maryland Department of Agriculture can manage the additional certifications with existing resources. Local governments are not expected to be materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Agriculture is the primary implementing agency for this bill. It manages the Pesticide Applicator’s Law, oversees the certification of applicators, regulates pesticide use, and will manage the Pesticide Fund which is expected to see a significant increase in special fund revenue.

The Department of Natural Resources is specifically identified in the fiscal note as a 'public agency applicator' that applies pesticides on state-owned lands. The bill's changes to certification and supervision requirements will directly impact its operational procedures for land management.

The Department of Transportation, through the State Highway Administration (SHA), acts as a 'public agency applicator' for roadside vegetation management. The bill's certification mandates for pesticide application apply to its employees and contractors.

The bill repeals regulations regarding toxic substances such as tributyltin (used in antifouling paint) and cyclodiene termiticides. These repeals align with the Department of the Environment's mission to protect Maryland's water and land resources from hazardous pollutants.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Agriculture and the Department of the Environment. It would be responsible for handling criminal or civil appeals and ensuring the new regulatory framework complies with state and federal laws.

The OAH provides an impartial forum for contested cases. Because the bill establishes new certification requirements and liability standards, the OAH may be required to adjudicate appeals regarding license denials or enforcement actions taken by the Department of Agriculture.

DBM is responsible for estimating state revenues and overseeing the executive budget. The bill is projected to increase state special fund revenues by at least $140,000 annually, which requires DBM monitoring.

The Governor's Office oversees all state departments, including the Department of Agriculture. The Governor is responsible for signing the bill into law and ensuring the executive branch enforces the updated pesticide regulations.

As the state's chief financial officer and revenue collector, the Comptroller monitors the collection of fees and the fiscal health of state funds, including the Pesticide Fund impacted by this legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Utility Transparency and Accountability Act requires electric companies, excluding municipal electric utilities, to submit an annual report to the Public Service Commission (PSC) by February 1 each year detailing all recorded votes cast by the company or its State affiliates at regional transmission organization (RTO) meetings during the previous calendar year.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Electric companies (excluding municipal electric utilities), State affiliates of electric companies, and the Maryland Public Service Commission.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State finances or operations, and it has no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that electric companies submit annual reports on Regional Transmission Organization (RTO) voting directly to the Public Service Commission, which is the primary state agency responsible for the oversight and regulation of these public utilities.

The bill addresses a transparency gap regarding utility voting at the RTO level, which is critical for the Office of the People's Counsel in its mission to advocate for the interests of residential utility consumers in energy-related regulatory matters.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the Public Service Commission and would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the interpretation and enforcement of the new reporting requirements for electric companies.

Decisions made through RTO voting outcomes influence wholesale electricity markets and the state's progress toward renewable energy goals, both of which are central to the MEA's energy policy and grant management work.

RTO voting can affect the energy generation mix and subsequent greenhouse gas emissions; as the lead agency for Maryland's climate change initiatives, the MDE has a policy interest in the transparency of utility positions on regional energy matters.

As the state's central fiscal and personnel authority, DBM manages the budget for the PSC and OPC; while the fiscal note indicates a non-material impact, DBM is responsible for the fiscal oversight of these implementing agencies.

The Governor's Office oversees the operations of executive agencies including the PSC and is responsible for enforcing state utility laws and supporting statewide initiatives related to economic opportunity and public policy.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the membership of the Maryland Correctional Training Commission by adding two new members: the Director of the Division of Parole and Probation and one employee of the Division of Parole and Probation. The bill also specifies that the newly added employee member may not designate a representative to attend meetings in their place.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Correctional Training Commission within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Director and employees of the Division of Parole and Probation, members of the Maryland Correctional Training Commission, and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State finances are not significantly affected. Any expense reimbursements for the additional commission members can be handled with existing resources. There is no local fiscal impact or impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Correctional Training Commission (CTC) and the Division of Parole and Probation (DPP) are both units within DPSCS. This bill, which was a departmental request from DPSCS, directly changes the membership of the CTC to include leadership and staff from the DPP.

The Secretary of Juvenile Services and a designated representative are statutory members of the Maryland Correctional Training Commission. As a core member of the commission, DJS is impacted by changes to the body's overall composition and membership structure.

The Attorney General of Maryland is a statutory member of the Maryland Correctional Training Commission. Changes to the membership of the commission directly affect a body on which the Attorney General serves.
The Governor is the appointing authority for several members of the commission, including the newly added parole and probation employee member introduced by this bill.

The Office of Appointments is responsible for identifying, recruiting, and vetting candidates for the Governor's appointments to state boards and commissions. They will manage the recruitment and vetting of the new parole and probation employee member.
MHEC is responsible for appointing one member of the Maryland Correctional Training Commission (specifically, a president of a university or college with a correctional education curriculum).

DBM oversees the state budget and personnel policies. The fiscal note indicates that expense reimbursements for the additional commission members will be handled using existing resources, which falls under DBM's fiscal oversight.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires wholesale buyers and wholesale sellers of residential property to provide specific written disclosures regarding the assignment of sales contracts. A wholesale buyer must disclose to the property owner that the contract may be assigned to another person, while a wholesale seller must disclose to a prospective assignee that they hold an equitable interest and may not be able to convey title. Failure to provide these disclosures allows the property owner or the assignee to rescind the contract without penalty before closing and entitles the rescinding party to a refund of any deposits.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor and the Office of the Attorney General (Consumer Protection Division)
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners of owner-occupied residential property, wholesale real estate buyers and sellers, and assignees of residential property contracts.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State or local government operations or finances. The impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill introduces mandatory disclosure requirements for wholesale buyers and sellers in residential property transactions. The Office of the Attorney General's Consumer Protection Division is cited in the fiscal note as a source of information and is responsible for protecting Maryland residents from unfair or deceptive trade practices, making the enforcement and oversight of these real estate disclosures relevant to their primary mission.

The bill creates new statutory rights for residential property owners and assignees to rescind contracts of sale and receive refunds of deposits if disclosure requirements are not met. As a result, the Judiciary—supported by the Administrative Office of the Courts—will be responsible for adjudicating contract disputes and litigation arising from these new legal provisions.

The Department of Labor is responsible for regulating various professional trades and includes the Office of Financial Regulation. Because this bill impacts the business practices and contractual disclosures of 'wholesale' real estate entities, the department has a regulatory interest in how these individuals operate within the state's marketplace.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the list of entities eligible to administer local rehabilitation programs under the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program to include nonprofit sponsors. This allows certified nonprofit organizations to originate and manage loans for housing rehabilitation, a role previously restricted to political subdivisions such as counties and municipalities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit organizations, local governments, and Maryland families of limited income in need of housing rehabilitation services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or local government finances. While there may be a redistribution of program funds from local jurisdictions to nonprofit sponsors for program administration, the overall impact on individual local jurisdictions is expected to be minimal. Small businesses, specifically contractors working with the Department of Housing and Community Development, are also expected to see minimal or no economic impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency for the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program, this bill directly expands DHCD's administrative responsibilities. The department is tasked with certifying nonprofit sponsors, establishing capability standards by regulation, and providing technical assistance and training to these new program administrators.

This is a departmental bill requested by the Moore administration. The Governor's Office provides executive oversight for the Department of Housing and Community Development and ensures the bill aligns with the administration's policy goals for community revitalization and housing availability.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to DHCD and would be responsible for reviewing and approving the new regulations required by the bill to certify nonprofit sponsors and define their administrative capabilities.

DBM serves as the state's central fiscal authority and manages the statewide personnel and budget system. They monitor DHCD's operating budget and the administrative resources needed to oversee the expansion of the Maryland Housing Rehabilitation Program to nonprofit entities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the prioritization and eligibility for projects receiving funding from the Bay Restoration Fund's Septics Account. It establishes new priority tiers for failing septic systems, specifically targeting those in the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area, nitrogen-impaired watersheds, and 500-year floodplains. The bill also expands eligibility for community sewerage systems and municipal sewer connections by replacing a fixed 2008 installation date requirement with a rolling 15-year requirement, and it extends funding for certain system repairs to moderate-income owners.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners of on-site sewage disposal systems (septic systems), low- and moderate-income homeowners, local governments, and local health departments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no net impact on State Bay Restoration Fund finances as the bill only modifies project prioritization and eligibility within the existing Septics Account. The Maryland Department of the Environment can implement the changes with existing resources. Local grant revenues and expenditures may shift between jurisdictions due to the updated priorities, though total local funding remains unchanged. Local health departments may experience a minimal increase in workload to administer the block grants under the new criteria.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) is the primary implementing agency for the bill. It is responsible for managing the Bay Restoration Fund (BRF) Septics Account, evaluating and ranking nitrogen removal technologies, and determining the priority of funding for septic system repairs and replacements.
The bill explicitly mandates the Comptroller to establish a separate account within the Bay Restoration Fund for septic fees and to disburse these funds according to the priorities set in the bill.

The bill references the transfer of 40% of the Bay Restoration Fund septic fee revenues to the Maryland Agriculture Water Quality Cost Share Program within the Department of Agriculture for cover crop activities. While the bill primarily modifies the Septics Account, the overall structure of the BRF impacts this department.

The bill links septic system upgrade eligibility to whether a property is located within a 'priority funding area' as defined by the State Finance and Procurement Article. The Department of Planning is responsible for coordinating land use and managing priority funding area designations.

The fiscal note identifies an operational impact on local health departments, which are overseen by the Maryland Department of Health. These local departments are often responsible for distributing block grants from MDE for septic upgrades.
As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM oversees the Bay Restoration Fund as part of the executive budget process and ensures fiscal accountability for the programs managed by MDE and MDA.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of the Environment and would be responsible for advising on the implementation and regulatory enforcement of the new prioritization and eligibility criteria.

The Governor's Office oversees all state departments mentioned in the bill and has the authority to sign or veto this legislation, which aligns with statewide environmental and Chesapeake Bay restoration goals.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the requirement for the State Department of Assessments and Taxation (SDAT) regarding the constant yield tax rate. Instead of automatically calculating and notifying all taxing authorities of the rate each year, SDAT is only required to provide this calculation and notification if specifically requested by a taxing authority by February 1.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland taxing authorities including county councils, boards of county commissioners, the Baltimore City Council, and governing bodies of municipal corporations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to result in minimal administrative cost savings for the State Department of Assessments and Taxation starting in fiscal 2026. There is no impact on local government revenues or expenditures, as the bill does not change existing local notification requirements for property tax rate increases.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Assessments and Taxation (SDAT) and facilitates departmental legislation designed to improve government operations and fiscal oversight.

DBM serves as the state's central fiscal authority and manages the statewide personnel and administrative efficiency of executive agencies. The fiscal note identifies potential administrative cost savings for SDAT, which falls under DBM's management oversight.

GOPI is responsible for identifying opportunities to eliminate duplication and waste in government. This bill streamlines a reporting process by changing a mandatory notification to an on-request system, directly aligning with the agency's modernization and efficiency goals.

The bill reenacts with amendments Tax-Property Section 2-205, which explicitly mentions the Maryland Tax Court. The statute requires SDAT to notify local taxing authorities of assessment changes resulting from Tax Court decisions.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of executive branch agencies. This bill alters a statutory reporting requirement for SDAT, which OLA would monitor to ensure the agency is complying with the new 'on request' notification standards.

The bill amends the section of the law (Section 2-205) that governs how SDAT communicates assessment changes to local governments. This section specifically references the board's actions as a trigger for required assessment updates.

The Council advocates for the interests of 18 rural counties and their municipal corporations. The bill affects how these local 'taxing authorities' receive critical tax rate data from the state, shifting the process to a request-based system.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill provides that the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, rather than the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board, is responsible for the reimbursement of physicians, health care providers, and hospitals for sexual assault forensic exams and HIV prevention treatments provided to victims of alleged rape or sexual offenses. This change codifies current administrative practice where a specific unit within the office handles these payments.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
qa_results.stakeholders: Victims of alleged rape, sexual offenses, or child sexual abuse; physicians; qualified health care providers; and hospitals.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State or local finances. According to the fiscal note, the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy already processes these reimbursements through its Sexual Assault Reimbursement Unit, and the bill simply clarifies existing practice in statute.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy as the primary entity responsible for the reimbursement of physicians, health care providers, and hospitals for sexual assault forensic exams and medical treatments, codifying existing administrative practice within the agency.

The bill involves the payment for medical services, including forensic exams and HIV postexposure prophylaxis (nPEP), which are performed by healthcare providers and hospitals regulated and coordinated by the Department of Health.

DHS oversees child welfare and protective services; the bill directly impacts the administrative process for ensuring forensic exams and treatments for victims of child sexual abuse are provided without charge.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees GOCPP and the administration of state-funded victim services and public safety initiatives affected by this statutory shift.

DBM oversees state agency spending and the executive budget; it is relevant as the bill formally shifts statutory fiscal responsibility for these medical payments from the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board to GOCPP's general administration.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to state agencies, including GOCPP, and would be responsible for advising on the implementation of these statutory changes to the Criminal Procedure Article.

The bill concerns the health and safety of child sexual abuse victims, aligning with the Governor's Office for Children's mission to lead policy efforts for child well-being and healthcare access for vulnerable youth.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the Maryland Trust Act to allow a trustee to resign from their position without court approval, provided they give at least 30 days' notice to all qualified beneficiaries, the settlor (if living), all co-trustees, and any person with the authority to appoint a successor trustee.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Trustees, trust beneficiaries, trust settlors, co-trustees, and individuals authorized to appoint successor trustees.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect Maryland State or local government finances. There is a minimal impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies the Maryland Trust Act's procedures for trustee resignation, moving from mandatory court approval to a notice-based process. This significantly impacts the Administrative Office of the Courts, which manages judicial policies, court forms, and training for judges and court personnel regarding fiduciary cases.

The Register of Wills serves as the administrative clerk for the Orphans' Court and manages records related to estates and trusts under the Estates and Trusts Article of the Maryland Code. This legislation changes the administrative and record-keeping requirements for trustee resignations, requiring the agency to update its forms and guidance for the public.

The Office of Financial Regulation within the Department of Labor supervises the state's financial services industry, including trust companies and banks acting in a fiduciary capacity. The simplified process for trustee resignation impacts the regulatory environment and operational standards for these professional entities.

The Office of the Attorney General acts as the primary legal advisor for the state and manages civil appeals. As the bill amends the Estates and Trusts Article, the OAG may be involved in advising state agencies that serve as trustees or beneficiaries and in interpreting the impact of these changes on state law.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing the bill into law and overseeing the general enforcement of state laws. While the impact is largely administrative for the judiciary, the office maintains broad oversight over changes to the Estates and Trusts Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the requirement for child care centers regarding the number of staff members who must be certified in first aid and CPR. It replaces the fixed statutory ratio of one certified staff member for every 20 children with a requirement that the Maryland State Department of Education establish the ratio through regulation.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Child care centers, child care center staff, and families with children in child care centers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland State Department of Education can implement the bill's changes with existing resources, resulting in no impact on state revenues or local government finances. Small businesses operating child care centers may benefit from reduced staff training costs and improved staff recruitment and retention.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary regulator for Maryland's child care system, MSDE is directly responsible for adopting rules and regulations for licensing and operating child care centers. This bill explicitly authorizes MSDE to set the ratio of CPR and first-aid certified staff to children in child care centers through regulation.

This is a departmental bill introduced at the request of the Maryland State Department of Education and was signed into law by the Governor. The office oversees the operations of state departments like MSDE.

The Governor's Office for Children leads a 'whole-of-government' approach to child well-being. Changes to staffing requirements in child care centers directly impact the safety, accessibility, and quality of care for children across the state.

The fiscal note identifies a meaningful economic impact on small businesses, specifically child care providers. The Department of Commerce is the state's primary agency for supporting small businesses and private investment.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for state agencies including MSDE. It would be responsible for reviewing the legality and sufficiency of the new regulations promulgated by MSDE following the enactment of this bill.

The bill involves monitoring health practices, preventing the spread of disease, and requiring CPR/First Aid certification in child care settings, which overlaps with the Department of Health's mission to promote public safety and community health standards.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill renames the Senior Call-Check Service and Notification Program to the Senior Call-Check and Social Connections Program and expands its mission. It lowers the eligibility age for participants from 65 to 60 and broadens communication methods from simple telephone calls to include text messages, video calls, and in-person interactions to promote wellness and reduce social isolation among older adults. It also integrates services with the Telecommunications Access of Maryland to assist participants with disabilities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Aging
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents age 60 and older, particularly those at risk of social isolation; individuals with disabilities; local government agencies; Area Agencies on Aging; and community-based volunteer organizations known as "Villages."
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill renames and expands the purpose of existing program funds. The fiscal 2026 budget includes $419,967 in special funds from the Universal Service Trust Fund (USTF) for the program. The Maryland Department of Aging can manage administrative changes with existing resources, though special fund expenditures may increase if additional contracts are established. Local government revenues and expenditures may increase if they enter into agreements with the State to provide program services.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, MDOA is responsible for establishing, administering, and adopting regulations for the newly renamed Senior Call-Check and Social Connections Program.

The bill mandates that MDOA integrate services with the Telecommunications Access of Maryland (TAM) program, which is managed by MDOD, and requires that all program communications be accessible to participants with disabilities.
This is a departmental bill representing the administration's policy priorities for senior wellness and social engagement; the Governor's Office also oversees the Department of Aging.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Aging and would be responsible for providing counsel regarding new regulations and contracts with private vendors or nonprofit organizations mentioned in the bill.
DBM oversees the state's operating budget and the Universal Service Trust Fund, which provides the special fund expenditures for the program as noted in the fiscal note.

The bill expands the program to include digital communication methods such as text, web-based, and virtual video platforms, which fall under DoIT's strategic oversight of state IT infrastructure and telecommunications.
The program's focus on wellness and social isolation for older adults overlaps with MDH's mission to protect public health and coordinate community health standards.
DHS is responsible for adult welfare services and shares a common constituency with this program, which targets vulnerable older adults at risk of social isolation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) to develop content standards for each subject at each grade level and mandates that county boards of education align their curriculum guides and courses of study with these standards. It establishes a formal process for the State Superintendent of Schools to identify discrepancies, require corrective plans from local school systems, and mandate the withholding of state funds from any local board that fails to comply with an approved corrective plan.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education and the State Superintendent of Schools
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland public school students, teachers, county boards of education, and local school superintendents.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: MSDE can develop content standards and provide notices using existing resources, though extensive reviews of local curricula may require additional or redirected staff. Local boards of education may incur minimal costs to update curricula. The bill requires the State Superintendent to withhold state funds from local boards that fail to implement corrective plans for curriculum discrepancies, although this is anticipated to occur rarely and is not expected to materially affect overall State expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MSDE is the primary implementing agency for this bill. It is responsible for developing content standards, curriculum standards, and curriculum resources for all subjects and grade levels. Additionally, the State Superintendent (as head of MSDE) is tasked with identifying curriculum discrepancies, approving local corrective plans, and directing the withholding of state funds for non-compliance.

The bill explicitly requires the State Superintendent to notify the State Comptroller to withhold state funds from a local board of education if they fail to comply with curriculum corrective plans. The Comptroller acts as the fiscal authority responsible for executing this withholding.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees MSDE and the State Superintendent. The Governor signed the bill, and the office is responsible for ensuring executive branch agencies effectively implement state educational standards and fiscal penalties.

The State Treasurer's Office manages the disbursement of state education aid. The bill’s enforcement mechanism involving the withholding of state funds directly impacts the Treasurer’s role in managing and disbursing public funds to local jurisdictions.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to MSDE. It would likely provide legal counsel regarding the development of state standards, the formal notice of discrepancy process, and the legal defense of any actions taken to withhold state funds from local boards.

DBM oversees the state budget and fiscal accountability. The bill’s provisions regarding the withholding of state appropriations to local boards of education involve the state’s central fiscal authority and impact the allocation of taxpayer resources.

The bill mandates that curriculum resources be designed to ensure students meet 'college and career readiness standards.' This alignment between K-12 education and future employment directly supports the GWDB's mission to build pathways into high-demand careers.

The OLA conducts fiscal and performance audits of executive agencies and local boards. The bill's requirement for local boards to align with state standards and the subsequent fiscal enforcement mechanisms provide new criteria for OLA to review during their regular accountability audits.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a reciprocal permit system allowing out-of-state motor home and recreational trailer dealers to display their vehicles at shows in Worcester County, provided their home state grants similar privileges to Maryland dealers. Permit holders are authorized only to exhibit vehicles and are strictly prohibited from executing sales contracts or accepting deposits at the shows.
qa_results.responsible_party: Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Out-of-state motor home and recreational trailer dealers, Maryland motor home dealers, and vehicle show organizers in Worcester County.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Motor Vehicle Administration can implement the permit system using existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on local government finances, and the potential impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA), which is a unit of the Maryland Department of Transportation, establish and issue the new out-of-state motor home and recreational trailer vehicle show permit.

The MVA is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill, including issuing the permits, determining the permit duration, and managing the bond filing and enforcement process for out-of-state dealers.
As the chief executive, the Governor's Office oversees all state departments including MDOT/MVA and is responsible for signing the legislation into law.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for the MVA and would likely assist in drafting regulations or bond forms required by the bill and ensuring legal compliance for reciprocal agreements with other states.
The bill impacts vehicle shows in Worcester County, which is a major tourism and business hub. The Department of Commerce is responsible for promoting tourism and economic development in the state.
Recreational vehicle shows in Worcester County (a key tourism region) attract visitors and domestic travel, aligning with this agency's mission to promote Maryland as a premier travel destination.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the expiration date for utilizing the Maternal and Child Health Population Health Improvement Fund from December 31, 2025, to December 31, 2027. This extension allows the Maryland Department of Health to continue spending residual funds on initiatives such as doula services, prenatal care, and childhood asthma programs instead of the funds expiring.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Health Services Cost Review Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Mothers and children in Maryland, Medicaid recipients, and healthcare providers participating in maternal and child health initiatives.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill allows up to $24.1 million in residual special funds to continue being expended through the first half of FY 2028. These funds will be used in place of general funds and will continue to be used to match federal fund revenues for Medicaid-related programs. There is no impact on local government finances, and no new special fund revenues are generated by this bill.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor’s Office oversees executive branch operations and signs or vetoes legislation. The Governor signed this bill into law, and the office oversees the departmental initiatives and budget allocations related to maternal and child health.
The bill explicitly states that the Comptroller of Maryland is responsible for accounting for the Maternal and Child Health Population Health Improvement Fund.
The bill requires the State Treasurer to hold the fund separately and invest the money in the fund, ensuring interest earnings are credited back to it.
The Department of Budget and Management oversees state expenditures, and the bill requires that all spending from this fund be made in accordance with the State budget.

The Maryland Department of Health is the primary agency responsible for administering the fund and implementing the maternal and child health programs through its Medicaid and Prevention and Health Promotion administrations.
The Health Services Cost Review Commission (HSCRC) joint-administers the fund, regulates the hospital assessments that generate the revenue, and must approve expenditures from the fund.
The bill explicitly designates the Maternal and Child Health Population Health Improvement Fund as subject to audit by the Office of Legislative Audits.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Davis Martinez Public Employee Safety and Health Act establishes the Public Employees’ Safety and Health Unit within the Maryland Department of Labor to oversee workplace safety for public employees. The bill removes the previous exemption of public bodies from occupational safety and health penalties, requires the adoption of workplace violence prevention standards, and mandates regulations and policies for the use of body-worn cameras by correctional officers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor, Correctional Training Commission, and the Office of the Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: State and local public employees, correctional officers, and public bodies including school districts and special districts.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: In FY 2026, State general fund expenditures increase by approximately $535,400 and special fund expenditures increase by $69,400 to cover staffing and body-worn camera implementation. Special fund revenues from civil penalties against public bodies are projected to increase by $30,000 in FY 2026 and $40,000 annually thereafter, with funds directed to the Maryland Apprenticeship and Training Program. Local governments may face increased costs for safety compliance and potential penalties.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency's Division of Labor and Industry is the primary entity responsible for establishing the Public Employees' Safety and Health (PESH) Unit, adopting workplace violence standards, and enforcing the Maryland Occupational Safety and Health Act on public bodies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill significantly impacts this agency by requiring the training, issuance, and use of body-worn cameras for correctional officers and requiring the development of specific internal policies and collective bargaining for their staff.
The office is required to prioritize administrative warrants, handle contested safety cases, and provide specific notifications to state leadership when public bodies are in violation of safety laws.

As a 'correctional unit' under Maryland law, the department is required to develop and maintain written policies for body-worn camera use and comply with new safety and reporting standards for its facilities and fieldwork locations.

The agency manages the state personnel system for all impacted public employees and coordinates the fiscal adjustments for agencies, such as MD Labor and the OAG, that require additional staffing to implement the bill.
This agency oversees collective bargaining for the public workforce; the bill identifies body-worn camera policies as a mandatory subject of bargaining between public bodies and employee unions.

The Administrative Office of the Courts must manage judicial procedures related to changes in the Wiretap Act, which is amended by the bill to allow correctional officers to legally intercept oral communications via body-worn cameras.

The bill requires the Governor to be formally notified by the Attorney General and the Commissioner of Labor and Industry regarding safety violations and the failure of public bodies to pay assessed civil penalties.
The agency is affected as a public body employer and is referenced in the bill's updates to standards for body-worn digital recording devices used by law enforcement and correctional officers.
