The bill is clarifying in nature, as business-to-business transactions were intended to be exempt, and the Fiscal and Policy Note for the legislation that originally established cannabis nurseries did not assume any sales and use tax revenues from these transactions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the state's chief tax collector. This bill was introduced at the request of the Comptroller to clarify and expand the sales and use tax exemption for cannabis transactions to include registered nurseries, which the agency is responsible for administering.

The MCA is the primary regulatory body for the cannabis industry in Maryland. The bill specifically relates to the tax status of businesses licensed and nurseries registered by the MCA under Title 36 of the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees the operations of the Maryland Cannabis Administration and is responsible for signing or vetoing the legislation. The bill originated as a departmental request within the executive branch.

DBM oversees the state's fiscal policy and revenue estimates. While the fiscal note indicates no significant impact, the agency monitors changes to the sales and use tax code for long-term fiscal planning.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the definition of a 'slot machine' to exclude skills-based amusement devices that award tickets, tokens, or prizes of minimal value per play, allowing these items to be accumulated and exchanged for noncash merchandise or prizes with a wholesale value of up to $599.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Operators and users of skills-based amusement devices, family entertainment centers, and arcade businesses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on state or local revenues or expenditures, as enforcement can be handled with existing resources. Small business impacts are expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the chief executive, the Governor signs the bill into law and oversees the executive branch agencies responsible for gaming regulation and criminal law enforcement.

The Comptroller acts as the state's fiscal watchdog and was consulted as a source for the bill's fiscal note; the office monitors economic impacts and business tax compliance related to amusement devices.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission and is responsible for interpreting the changes to the Criminal Law Article and ensuring the rule of law.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This is the primary regulatory agency for gaming; the bill explicitly tasks the Commission within this agency to define the 'minimal value' for skill-based amusement device prizes through regulation and oversee compliance.

As the state's primary law enforcement agency, the MSP investigates illegal gaming; the bill's change to the definition of 'slot machine' in the Criminal Law Article directly affects their enforcement and investigative boundaries.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office serves as the state's central hub for public safety policy and advises the Governor on criminal justice strategies, including changes to the Criminal Law Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Income Tax Reconciliation Program to assist justice-involved individuals who were unable to file income tax returns during their incarceration. Eligible individuals who were sentenced to between 6 months and 10 years in prison can apply for a 10-year installment payment plan for unpaid taxes and receive a waiver for all associated interest and penalties for tax years 2025 through 2029.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller
qa_results.stakeholders: Justice-involved individuals currently serving or recently released (within 2 years) from a prison sentence of 6 months to 10 years, excluding those who committed crimes while holding elected office.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues and local income tax revenues will decrease by an indeterminate amount starting in FY 2026 due to the waiver of interest and penalty collections. The Comptroller's Office is expected to handle the administrative requirements of the program using existing budgeted resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates the Comptroller to establish and administer the Income Tax Reconciliation Program, manage installment payment plans, waive interest and penalties, and adopt program regulations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Comptroller to collaborate with this department to develop an awareness campaign. The department also manages the State correctional facilities where the target population is incarcerated.
The bill requires the court to inform defendants about the program during sentencing for certain crimes. The AOC supports the judiciary and manages court policy implementation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency represents indigent defendants facing potential imprisonment, who are the primary population targeted by this tax reconciliation program.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office is the state's hub for criminal justice policy and would oversee the broader impact of the program on justice-involved individuals.
The Governor serves as the chief executive who signed the bill into law and oversees the implementing departments.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for the agencies implementing the program and would likely be involved in drafting regulations.
This court adjudicates tax controversies and would handle appeals related to tax assessments or program eligibility determinations.
DBM estimates state revenues and manages the fiscal impact of tax-related legislation, including the forgone interest and penalties under this program.
OLA performs fiscal compliance audits of the Comptroller's office and will monitor the lawful administration of the installment plans and waivers.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program (LARP) to include veterinary practitioners and veterinary technicians. To be eligible, these individuals must have received a degree from an accredited veterinary college or university and provided veterinary services as an employee in Maryland for at least five years, or as a volunteer for at least 100 hours per year for at least three years at specified animal shelters.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission (Office of Student Financial Assistance)
qa_results.stakeholders: Veterinary practitioners, veterinary technicians, and animal shelters owned by local governments or specific non-profit organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not mandate additional spending for the program, as new applicants may be placed on a waiting list if current appropriations (approximately $4.1 million for fiscal 2026) are insufficient. However, the Maryland Higher Education Commission will incur a one-time cost of approximately $8,000 in fiscal 2026 for software upgrades. Each individual award averages about $5,800. There is no impact on local government revenues or expenditures, though local animal shelters may benefit from increased staffing or volunteers.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Higher Education Commission, through its Office of Student Financial Assistance, is the primary implementing agency for the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program. This bill directly expands the program's eligibility to include veterinary practitioners and technicians, requiring the Commission to manage new applications, update its processing systems (MDCAPS), and conduct publicity.

The bill defines eligibility for the loan program based on service at shelters that are recipients of the Maryland Spay and Neuter Grants Program, which is administered by the Department of Agriculture. MDA also provided critical data for the fiscal note regarding the veterinary industry and grant recipients.

The Department of Budget and Management oversees the state's annual budget and the appropriation of funds for the Janet L. Hoffman LARP. DBM is responsible for managing the program's funding levels, which the fiscal note indicates may be impacted by the increased number of eligible applicants.

The University System of Maryland oversees the public institutions that graduate many of the veterinary practitioners and technicians who would benefit from this program. USM is also tasked with workforce development in high-demand fields, making the incentives provided by this bill relevant to their strategic goals.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing the legislation and overseeing the agencies (specifically MHEC and MDA) tasked with implementing the expanded eligibility for the loan repayment program.

The Department of Health has a role within the Janet L. Hoffman LARP statute to determine 'high-need geographic areas' for other medical and counseling professions. While they do not lead the veterinary expansion, they are involved in the overall regulatory framework of the program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the existence and reporting deadline of the Task Force on the Creation of a Division of Returning Citizens and Expanded Reentry Services. The deadline for the task force to submit its final report to the General Assembly is moved from December 31, 2025, to October 31, 2026, and the termination date for the task force is extended from June 30, 2026, to June 30, 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS)
qa_results.stakeholders: Returning citizens (formerly incarcerated individuals) and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect state or local operations or finances. Any additional expenses for task force member reimbursements or staffing costs for the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on revenues.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS is responsible for staffing the Task Force and is the designated agency to house the proposed new Division of Returning Citizens and Expanded Reentry Services. The bill extends their administrative and staffing responsibilities by one year.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly extends the lifespan and reporting deadline of a task force that falls under this functional category of state-authorized study groups.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's central hub for public safety policy, GOCPP is a key stakeholder in the task force's findings regarding reentry strategies and recidivism reduction programs.
The Governor's Office oversees executive branch task forces and coordinates statewide initiatives aimed at public safety and economic opportunity for vulnerable populations.
The creation of a new state division as proposed by the task force would require coordination with DBM regarding personnel management, budget formulation, and organizational efficiency.
The task force focuses on reentry services, which heavily involve workforce development and job training programs administered by the Department of Labor.
Expanded reentry services typically include behavioral health and substance use disorder treatment, which are core public health services managed by this agency.
DHS provides social service support and economic assistance programs that are critical to the stabilization of returning citizens.
GOPI tracks progress on the Governor's priorities and identifies opportunities to modernize government services, such as the proposed creation of a new division for returning citizens.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a temporary to-go event permit and a Class C per diem municipal to-go beer, wine, and liquor license in Wicomico County. It allows municipalities to designate special event areas where patrons can consume alcoholic beverages in approved to-go cups sold by participating Class B license holders located within or adjacent to the area.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Wicomico County
qa_results.stakeholders: Municipalities in Wicomico County, Class B beer, wine, and liquor license holders, and patrons attending special events in the county.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state fiscal impact. Wicomico County revenues will increase beginning in fiscal 2026 from the collection of license fees ($45 per day) and permit fees ($20 per day). The total revenue increase depends on the number of licenses and permits issued and cannot be reliably estimated. The county is expected to manage enforcement and administration using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the principal executive authority, the Governor signed this local legislation into law and oversees the executive boards responsible for its implementation, including the Wicomico County Board of License Commissioners.
This office identifies and vets candidates for the Wicomico County Board of License Commissioners, the body responsible for issuing these new permits and adopting the required regulations.
The Comptroller acts as the state's tax collector and is responsible for collecting sales and use taxes on the alcoholic beverages sold under the new temporary to-go permits and municipal licenses.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for the state and would provide counsel regarding the interpretation and enforcement of the new provisions added to the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article.
The bill facilitates economic growth for small businesses (restaurants and hotels) in Wicomico County by providing additional retail opportunities through temporary permits.
The creation of municipal to-go licenses and event permits supports heritage tourism and local festivals, which are key components of the MOTD's mission to promote Maryland as a travel destination.

The Council advocates for economic development and improved quality of life in Maryland's 18 rural counties, including Wicomico; this bill provides a new tool for municipal revitalization in a rural area.
The designation of special event areas for alcohol consumption may impact state-owned multi-modal transportation networks or require coordination for municipal events near state infrastructure.

As the SHA maintains state-numbered highways, any municipal 'to-go event' areas that encompass or cross state roads would require coordination with this agency for traffic management or road closures.
The OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of state and local boards, including county liquor boards, to ensure that licensing fees are handled in accordance with state law and financial controls.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill makes administrative changes to the Juvenile Services Education Board, including authorizing designees for the Secretary of Higher Education and the State Superintendent of Schools, staggering terms for appointed members, and limiting them to two consecutive terms. It also adjusts meeting requirements to a minimum of 10 times per year and no more than once per month, excluding special meetings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Juvenile Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Juvenile Services Education Board members, Department of Juvenile Services educators, and juveniles in State-operated residential facilities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no State or local fiscal impact because the bill is procedural in nature and does not affect revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Superintendent of Schools is a statutory member of the Juvenile Services Education Board. This bill allows the Superintendent to appoint a designee and alters the meeting frequency and terms of the Board they serve on.

The Department of Juvenile Services is the primary agency responsible for the Juvenile Services Education Board, providing its staff and overseeing the programs the Board governs. The Secretary of Juvenile Services is a Board member and has the authority to call special meetings under the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Juvenile Services Education Board functions as a specialized executive body. The bill directly alters the administrative structure, meeting requirements, and membership terms for this entity.

The Governor is responsible for appointing the majority of the Board members with Senate consent. The bill modifies the appointment structure by staggering terms and imposing term limits, directly impacting the Governor's executive appointment duties.

The Secretary of Higher Education is a statutory member of the Juvenile Services Education Board. The bill authorizes the Secretary to select a designee to serve in their place and changes the operational requirements of the Board.

This office manages the recruitment and vetting process for the Governor's board appointments. The bill's requirements to stagger terms and implement a randomized lottery for term terminations on specific dates will be executed through this office.

The Attorney General is a statutory member of the Juvenile Services Education Board. While the bill primarily focuses on the designees of other members and meeting schedules, it affects the board on which the Attorney General serves.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill clarifies and expands the disciplinary actions the State Board of Nursing may take regarding direct-entry midwife licenses. Specifically, it allows the Board to grant a license that is subject to a reprimand, probation, or suspension, in addition to its existing authority to deny, suspend, or revoke licenses for violations of professional standards.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Nursing
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed direct-entry midwives and applicants for direct-entry midwifery licenses
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no fiscal or operational impact on the State Board of Nursing. There is no impact on local government finances. Small business impacts are expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the Health Occupations Article concerning the State Board of Nursing, which is a regulatory unit under the Maryland Department of Health. The agency is responsible for the licensing and oversight of health professions, including direct-entry midwives.

The bill specifies that disciplinary actions are subject to statutory hearing provisions. The OAH provides the independent Administrative Law Judges who conduct formal hearings for contested cases involving the Department of Health and its boards.

The OAG serves as the chief legal advisor to nearly all state agencies, including the State Board of Nursing. It provides legal representation and counsel regarding disciplinary procedures and statutory interpretations for health occupations.

As the central fiscal authority, DBM estimates state revenues and manages the state budget. Although the fiscal note indicates no direct impact, DBM monitors changes to agency regulatory powers and operational mandates.
The Governor's Office oversees all state departments and signs or vetoes legislation passed by the General Assembly, including laws governing health profession regulations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid) and private health insurance carriers to provide coverage for calcium score testing for individuals with specific risk factors, including high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and a family history of premature coronary artery disease, in accordance with the most recent guidelines from the American College of Cardiology.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland Medicaid participants, health insurance carriers, health maintenance organizations, nonprofit health service plans, and individuals with cardiovascular risk factors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Medicaid expenditures may increase minimally (50% general funds, 50% federal funds) if the bill leads to higher utilization of calcium score testing, though the service is currently covered. The Maryland Insurance Administration will receive a minimal increase in special fund revenue from one-time filing fees in fiscal 2026. Local governments may see an increase in expenditures for health insurance premiums if they purchase fully insured plans.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid), which is administered by the Department of Health, to provide coverage for calcium score testing beginning January 1, 2026.

The bill establishes new coverage mandates under the Insurance Article, and the Maryland Insurance Administration is responsible for regulating insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and HMOs to ensure compliance, including the review of rate and form filings.
The commission is responsible for health system planning and commissioned the specific fiscal impact analysis (via Milliman) used to determine the bill's effect on premiums and utilization.
The mandate applies to qualified health plans offered through the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange, which must incorporate state-mandated benefits into their platform and eligibility determinations.

The Department of Budget and Management oversees the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program, which is evaluated in the fiscal note for potential premium increases due to the mandate.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Health and the Maryland Insurance Administration, assisting in the interpretation and enforcement of the new statutory requirements.
As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the primary departments (Health, DBM, MIA) tasked with implementing the new law and signed the legislation into effect.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) and the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) to jointly conduct an annual assessment of the school health and wellness personnel workforce in Maryland. The assessment includes identifying student-to-provider ratios, vacancy rates, and strategies for improving recruitment and retention. The bill also adds a school nurse member to the Maryland Council on Advancement of School–Based Health Centers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: School health and wellness personnel (including counselors, dental hygienists, occupational therapists, physical therapists, school nurses, school psychologists, and social workers), local school systems, local health departments, and Maryland students.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no fiscal effect in FY 2026. Starting in FY 2027, State general fund expenditures increase by $61,700 to hire one part-time health policy analyst at the Maryland Department of Health to coordinate data collection and annual reporting. Annual expenditures are projected to be between $57,700 and $62,900 through FY 2030. Local school systems and health departments can manage the data reporting requirements using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates the Maryland Department of Health to jointly conduct an annual assessment of the school health and wellness personnel workforce, submit a report to the General Assembly, and publish the findings. Additionally, the Secretary of Health is an ex-officio member of the Maryland Council on Advancement of School–Based Health Centers, and the fiscal note identifies a direct expenditure increase for a new analyst position within the department to handle these tasks.

The State Department of Education is jointly responsible for conducting the annual workforce assessment and reporting the findings. The State Superintendent of Schools also serves as an ex-officio member of the Maryland Council on Advancement of School–Based Health Centers, and the department will be required to coordinate with local school systems to gather data on vacancy rates and recruitment strategies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies the composition and voting membership of the Maryland Council on Advancement of School–Based Health Centers, an advisory body that fits the description of this functional designation within the executive branch.

As a centralized hub for school safety coordination that bridges the gap between students and mental health professionals, this agency is a key stakeholder in the assessment of school health and wellness personnel, including counselors and psychologists.

The Governor is responsible for appointing the 16 voting members of the Maryland Council on Advancement of School–Based Health Centers, and the bill specifically adds a new member (a school nurse) to this group.

This office is responsible for vetting candidates to serve on the state’s boards and commissions. It will manage the recruitment and vetting process for the new school nurse member added to the Maryland Council on Advancement of School–Based Health Centers.

The fiscal note identifies a fiscal impact requiring the creation of a new part-time position at the Maryland Department of Health. DBM acts as the central personnel and budget authority responsible for approving and managing such positions and fund allocations.

The Executive Director of the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange is a named ex-officio member of the Maryland Council on Advancement of School–Based Health Centers, the composition of which is altered by the bill.

The GOC leads a 'whole-of-government' approach to children's well-being, including access to mental health and healthcare services, which aligns with the bill’s goals of assessing the school-based health and wellness workforce.

The workforce assessment specifically includes personnel categories such as occupational therapists, physical therapists, and speech-language pathologists, who are critical to providing services to students with disabilities—a cross-disability policy area overseen by this department.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits a person from knowingly and willfully dismembering, destroying, removing, burying, or disposing of human remains with the intent to conceal a crime. It also prohibits aiding or abetting another person in these acts, classifying the offense as a felony punishable by up to five years in prison.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals involved in criminal activities related to human remains, law enforcement agencies, the Maryland judicial system, and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund incarceration expenditures may increase minimally due to the bill's five-year felony penalty provision. The bill is not expected to materially affect local finances or operations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill creates a new felony offense punishable by up to five years in prison, which will directly impact incarceration expenditures and the population levels of state correctional and community supervision facilities.

The judicial branch will be responsible for adjudicating and managing the trial processes for cases arising from the new criminal offense of dismembering or burying human remains with the intent to conceal a crime.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency is tasked with providing legal representation for indigent residents facing potential loss of liberty, and this new felony statute will lead to an increased caseload for its attorneys.

As the primary statewide law enforcement authority, the Maryland State Police will investigate instances of remains disposal and destruction intended to facilitate the concealment of criminal activity.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency advises the Governor on criminal justice strategies and manages public safety policy and data-driven insights related to new criminal statutes and prosecution.
The OAG manages all criminal appeals in state courts and provides legal counsel to the executive branch regarding the implementation and enforcement of the Criminal Law Article.
The agency maintains vital death records and regulates legal methods of body disposal, which provides the regulatory context for existing laws mentioned in the bill's analysis.
The Governor's Office signed the legislation into law and oversees the principal executive agencies responsible for criminal investigations, corrections, and judicial coordination.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the purpose and authorized uses of the Rape Kit Testing Grant Fund to include funding for the Office of the Attorney General to assist in investigations of untested kits collected before October 1, 2020, a statewide victim notification hotline, and peer-to-peer telehealth programs. It also extends the reporting deadline for the Sexual Assault Evidence Collection Kit Tracking Program to March 31, 2026, and allows the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy to issue grants for terms up to 36 months.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
qa_results.stakeholders: Victims of sexual assault, law enforcement agencies, forensic laboratories, the Office of the Attorney General, State's Attorneys, healthcare providers, and the State sexual assault coalition.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures for the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy will increase as the grant fund's purposes are expanded; the FY 2026 budget includes $3.5 million for the fund. The Office of the Attorney General will see an increase in grant revenues and expenditures to support investigations. Local law enforcement agencies and State's Attorney offices benefit from investigative assistance and an extended reporting deadline.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is the primary administrator of the Rape Kit Testing Grant Fund and the Sexual Assault Evidence Collection Kit Tracking Program. The Executive Director of this office is specifically charged with establishing procedures for fund distribution, ensuring access for jurisdictions, and submitting annual reports to the General Assembly.

The bill expands the purpose of the Rape Kit Testing Grant Fund specifically to provide funding to the Office of the Attorney General to assist law enforcement investigations of crimes involving sexual assault evidence collection kits collected before October 1, 2020.

As a law enforcement agency explicitly defined in the bill, the Department of State Police is eligible for grant funding for testing kits and is subject to the reporting requirements and deadlines for the sexual assault evidence collection kit tracking program.

The bill expands the use of the Rape Kit Testing Grant Fund to support peer-to-peer telehealth programs. As the agency responsible for public health services and healthcare financing, this aligns with the Department of Health's mission.

The bill explicitly mandates that the Comptroller shall account for the Rape Kit Testing Grant Fund, which is consistent with the agency's role as the state's chief financial officer and fiscal watchdog.
The bill explicitly mandates that the State Treasurer shall hold the Rape Kit Testing Grant Fund separately and invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money.

This agency oversees the state's budget process. The fiscal note indicates that the bill affects special fund expenditures and requires monitoring of appropriations for the Rape Kit Testing Grant Fund.

The Governor's Office oversees the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy (GOCPP). The bill also requires reports to be submitted and funds to be administered under the executive branch's authority.
The Lieutenant Governor leads significant statewide initiatives focused on public safety, which includes the response to sexual assault and the management of evidence collection kits.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill mandates that the Governor include an annual appropriation of $450,000 for the Maryland Deaf Culture Digital Library in the state budget beginning in fiscal year 2026. It also requires the library to submit its annual operating budget to the Maryland State Library Agency by June 1 of each year.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Library Agency
qa_results.stakeholders: Deaf and hard of hearing individuals, Maryland library patrons, and State and county library staff.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by approximately $49,000 annually beginning in fiscal 2026. While the bill mandates a $450,000 appropriation, the current baseline budget for the Maryland Deaf Culture Digital Library is $401,000, resulting in a net increase of $49,000. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Library Agency (MSLA) oversees the Deaf Culture Digital Library (DCDL). The bill requires DCDL to submit its annual operating budget to MSLA and mandates continued coordination between the two for program development and information sharing.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates the DCDL to coordinate with this office to provide sensitivity training for library staff and to select members for the newly formed Deaf Culture Digital Library Advisory Board.

The bill establishes a $450,000 mandated annual appropriation for the DCDL starting in FY 2026. As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM is responsible for incorporating this mandate into the annual operating budget.

The bill requires the Governor to include a specific mandated appropriation in the annual budget bill and oversees the executive coordination between the State Library Agency and the Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates the Deaf Culture Digital Library Advisory Board, a specialized body tasked with providing advice on initiatives to advance the library's mission and goals.
The bill directs the DCDL to develop partnerships and strategic alliances with senior citizens organizations, which falls under the advocacy and service mission of the Maryland Department of Aging.

The bill specifically requires the DCDL to develop partnerships and strategic alliances with veterans' groups, making it relevant to the department's role as a resource hub and advocate for the veteran community.

As the state’s cross-disability policy leader, the Department of Disabilities is relevant to any initiative aimed at improving resource accessibility and specialized services for Marylanders with disabilities, including the deaf and hard of hearing.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill limits the circumstances under which the Child Support Administration can notify the Motor Vehicle Administration to suspend a driver's license for non-payment of child support. It generally exempts individuals with an annual income at or below 250% of the federal poverty guidelines from license suspension, unless they are judicially determined to be voluntarily impoverished. Additionally, it extends the non-compliance period for noncommercial license holders from 60 to 120 days before suspension proceedings begin and requires courts to provide child support orders and guideline calculations to the Child Support Administration.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services (Child Support Administration), Maryland Department of Transportation (Motor Vehicle Administration), and the Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Child support obligors (especially low-income individuals), child support recipients, the Child Support Administration, the Motor Vehicle Administration, and Maryland circuit courts.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures increase by $125,000 in FY 2026 for one-time programming costs within the Department of Human Services. There is a potential for significant annual expenditure increases for additional caseworkers, estimated by DHS at $2.0 million, though this amount is disputed by the Department of Legislative Services. General fund revenues are expected to decrease minimally due to fewer citations for driving with a suspended license. The Judiciary and local circuit courts will experience increased clerical and operational workloads to provide mandated documentation.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the court, after establishing a child support order, to send a copy of the guideline calculation and the order to the Child Support Administration. The fiscal note indicates this will have a significant operational impact on the circuit courts due to the high volume of cases (potentially over 50,000 additional cases per year).

The Child Support Administration is a unit of DHS. The bill alters the criteria and thresholds for CSA's child support enforcement actions, requires the agency to manage new income-based exemptions, and mandates the receipt of additional court documentation. DHS expects significant fiscal impact for caseworkers and IT system reprogramming.

MDOT is the parent agency of the Motor Vehicle Administration. The bill amends the Transportation Article to change the legal timeframes and requirements for suspending driver's licenses due to child support noncompliance.

The MVA is the primary agency responsible for executing the suspension and reinstatement of driver's licenses as directed by the Child Support Administration. It is also responsible for issuing work-restricted licenses for eligible obligors.

The bill designates the Office of Administrative Hearings as the venue for obligors to appeal the results of child support investigations regarding license suspensions. It also requires the Secretary of Human Services to cooperate with OAH in adopting implementing regulations.

As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM will be involved in the projected increase in general and federal fund expenditures for DHS and the Judiciary, as well as the personnel requests for additional caseworkers cited in the fiscal note.
The bill requires $125,000 in one-time programming costs for the Department of Human Services to update its systems. DoIT oversees state IT strategic direction and policy.

License reinstatement is tied to an obligor's participation and compliance in employment programs approved by the Child Support Administration. The Department of Labor manages the state's workforce development and apprenticeship programs.

The office leads 'whole-of-government' approaches to eliminate childhood poverty and increase family economic mobility. Changes to child support enforcement rules, particularly income thresholds for struggling parents, directly intersect with its policy mission.

The team is responsible for data-driven initiatives to reduce childhood poverty and increase economic mobility. This legislation, which adjusts enforcement mechanisms to prevent license suspensions that might hinder a low-income parent's ability to work, aligns with their policy focus.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for state agencies. It would be involved in the development of regulations and provides legal representation for the Child Support Administration and MVA in contested cases.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes new classes of alcoholic beverages licenses in Garrett County, specifically for deluxe complex restaurants and resort complexes. It also updates the application procedures and notice requirements for various festival licenses and clarifies that nonprofit organizations are eligible for certain multiple-day and multiple-event licenses.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Garrett County
qa_results.stakeholders: Restaurant and resort owners in Garrett County, nonprofit organizations, event organizers, and the Garrett County Board of License Commissioners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no impact on State finances. Garrett County revenues are expected to increase starting in fiscal 2026 as a result of new license fees and one-time issuing fees. The county is expected to manage enforcement and administration within its existing budget.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the chief executive, the Governor signed the bill into law and oversees the executive agencies responsible for enforcing the state’s Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for the state and its agencies; it provides legal guidance and ensures the rule of law regarding the implementation and regulation of the Garrett County alcoholic beverages code.
The creation of specialized deluxe restaurant and resort complex licenses is intended to stimulate private investment and support the expansion of the hospitality industry in Maryland.
Garrett County is a major tourism hub, and the expansion of festival and resort-based alcohol licenses directly impacts the heritage tourism and travel activities promoted by this agency.
The Comptroller acts as the state’s tax collector and fiscal watchdog; new licenses affect business tax collection and the office maintains oversight of various business licenses and state revenues.
The Council advocates for the economic interests and sustainability of Maryland’s 18 rural counties, including Garrett County, by supporting policy changes that foster local business growth.
The OAH provides an impartial forum for resolving contested cases; appeals related to the issuance or regulation of these new local licenses may be heard by Administrative Law Judges.
The State Police enforce statewide criminal laws and often facilitate the background investigations or enforcement activities required for the issuance of new alcoholic beverages licenses.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes uniform definitions related to the uniformed services across several sections of the Maryland Code, aligning them with federal standards. It expands eligibility for various state benefits, including reemployment rights for government employees, income tax subtraction modifications for military pay and retirement, and certain property tax relief programs, to include members and veterans of the Commissioned Corps of the Public Health Service and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, as well as the National Guard.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans and Military Families
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of the uniformed services (including the Armed Forces, Public Health Service, and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration), veterans, and their families.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local finances are not materially affected because the expanded definitions apply to a limited number of additional cases. The population of Public Health Service and NOAA officers in Maryland is small compared to the total veteran population, allowing any minor impact on tax revenues or personnel expenditures to be absorbed by existing agency resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary state advocate for veterans and military families, this agency is directly impacted by the bill's expansion of the definitions of 'veteran' and 'service member' to include the broader 'uniformed services' (including NOAA and PHS), which determines who qualifies for various state benefits and advocacy services.

The bill establishes significant income tax subtraction modifications and abatements for military pay and retirement income for the expanded uniformed services, which the Comptroller must administer as the state’s chief tax collector.

The DBM oversees the state's personnel system, and this bill makes substantive changes to state personnel law regarding reemployment rights, reinstatement, and hiring credits for members of the uniformed services.

The bill amends the State Personnel and Pensions Article to alter how seniority and service credit are calculated for members of the uniformed services, directly impacting the pension and retirement rights managed by this agency.

As an executive-led initiative by the Moore-Miller administration, the Governor’s Office is responsible for the overall policy direction and coordination of these equity and tax relief measures across state departments.

The bill expands eligibility for property tax relief and credits for disabled renters and veterans of the uniformed services; this board has jurisdiction over appeals related to these specific tax credit programs.

The bill explicitly expands benefits to the Public Health Service (PHS) commissioned corps and includes provisions for tax abatements related to public health emergency response, both of which overlap with the MDH workforce and mission.

MDOT manages large personnel units and the Motor Vehicle Administration; the bill's changes to military definitions and personnel rights (reinstatement, hiring credits) affect their workforce management.
The MSP employs many veterans and reservists who are directly impacted by the updated personnel and retirement credit rules established in this bill.
USM institutions employ veterans and are subject to the pension and personnel modifications regarding military service credit and reemployment rights.

The OAG will provide legal counsel to multiple state agencies regarding the interpretation and implementation of the revised 'uniformed services' definitions across different articles of the Maryland Code.
The Judiciary and its personnel are subject to the state personnel and pension updates regarding military service credits and reemployment rights mentioned in the bill.
The bill specifically applies reemployment rights for uniformed services to county boards of education, which are overseen by the State Department of Education.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency was consulted for the fiscal note as it uses veteran definitions for socioeconomic procurement programs, such as the Veteran-Owned Small Business Enterprise program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland counties that impose development impact fees, surcharges, or excise taxes to submit an annual report to the Maryland Department of Planning detailing the collection and expenditure of these funds. The reports must include the total amount of fees collected, the location of the developments where they were derived, and the specific capital improvement projects, such as school construction or transportation maintenance, that were funded by these revenues. Additionally, counties must submit their authorizing local laws to the department and make the reporting data available to the public on their websites.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Planning
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland county governments, the Maryland Department of Planning, and property developers or entities involved in new construction projects.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State or local operations or finances. The Maryland Department of Planning and local governments can comply with the bill's reporting and administrative requirements using existing resources. While 15 counties currently collect approximately $186.3 million in development-related fees and taxes annually, the bill does not alter the collection or expenditure levels of these funds.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the Department of Planning as the primary state agency responsible for receiving and collecting annual reports from counties regarding the collection, expenditure, and authorizing laws of development impact fees and excise taxes.
As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees the Department of Planning and the broader implementation of state reporting requirements mandated by this legislation.

Because the bill requires reporting on development impact fees used for school construction and maintenance, the resulting data is directly relevant to the IAC's oversight of public school facility funding and infrastructure.

The legislation requires reporting on fees used for transportation improvements and maintenance, which provides critical data relevant to MDOT's mission of managing and planning the state's transportation network.

As the state's central fiscal authority, DBM monitors the efficiency and transparency of public resources; the collection of fiscal data regarding local impact fees aligns with their role in statewide fiscal accountability.
The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Planning and would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the implementation and enforcement of the new county reporting requirements.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates 'Smart Growth' efforts; since impact fees are a primary mechanism for balancing development with environmental and infrastructure needs, the data collected under this bill is essential to its strategic mission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of 'honorable discharge' for the purpose of determining eligibility for State programs of benefits, rights, or privileges applicable to veterans in Maryland. It includes discharges that are less than honorable if they were based on the individual's sexual orientation or gender identity, or if the Department of Veterans and Military Families determines the individual is eligible for State benefits based on specific federal criteria (38 C.F.R. § 3.12).
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans and Military Families
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland veterans with less-than-honorable discharges, specifically those discharged due to sexual orientation, gender identity, or other conditions meeting federal benefit eligibility criteria.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Department of Veterans and Military Families (DVMF) can implement the bill's requirements using existing budgeted resources. While the bill expands the pool of veterans eligible for State benefits, it is not expected to materially affect State finances. However, the DVMF may incur some costs using general funds if it must cover expenses for veterans who qualify for State benefits but are ineligible for federal per diem reimbursements for nursing home care or burial costs. Local government operations and finances are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for advocating for and delivering benefits to Maryland veterans, this bill directly impacts their core operations. The Secretary of Veterans and Military Families is specifically tasked with receiving discharge documentation and the department must determine eligibility for state benefits based on expanded criteria.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency oversees the Veteran-Owned Small Business Enterprise (VSBE) program. By expanding the definition of 'honorable discharge' for all state programs, this bill likely increases the number of individuals eligible to certify their businesses for veteran-owned procurement preferences.

The fiscal note indicates a potential impact on the state budget. Specifically, the state may lose federal per diem reimbursements for veterans at the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home if their eligibility is recognized under this new state definition but not by federal standards, requiring the general fund to absorb these costs.

MHEC administers over $100 million in annual financial aid, including scholarships and tuition waivers specifically for veterans. Expanding the definition of 'honorable discharge' will expand the pool of students eligible for these state-funded educational benefits.

The Department of Labor manages workforce development and apprenticeship programs that often provide priority or specialized services to veterans. This bill changes the qualifying criteria for these 'State programs of benefits, rights, or privileges.'

DHCD administers housing programs for veterans, including homelessness prevention and mortgage assistance. Expanding the definition of 'honorable discharge' will increase the number of residents eligible for these specialized housing services.

The Comptroller manages state tax credits and revenue. To the extent that 'veteran' status grants specific tax exemptions or income exclusions under Maryland law, this expanded definition will impact tax administration and revenue forecasting.

Through the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA), MDOT handles veteran designation on driver's licenses and the issuance of specialized veteran license plates. A broader definition of honorable discharge will affect eligibility for these designations.

As the primary legal advisor to state agencies, the OAG will likely be required to provide guidance to various departments on how to apply the new definition of 'honorable discharge' across diverse state programs and benefits.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires each local board of education to publish on its website a list of special education service delivery models available for parentally-placed private school students with disabilities within their jurisdiction.
qa_results.responsible_party: Each county board of education
qa_results.stakeholders: Parentally-placed private school students with disabilities, their parents or guardians, and local school systems.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no impact on State revenues or expenditures. Local school systems are expected to implement the publication requirements using existing resources. Some school systems, such as Prince George's and Wicomico counties, already publish this information.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) oversees the state's public K-12 system and is responsible for implementing federal and state special education laws, including the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA). This bill directly modifies the Education Article concerning special education service delivery models, falling under MSDE's regulatory and oversight authority over county boards of education.

The Maryland Department of Disabilities (MDOD) is the cross-disability policy leader for the state, responsible for advocating for the rights of individuals with disabilities and guiding state policy on accessible services. This bill impacts the transparency and availability of disability-related services in the education sector.

The Governor's Office for Children coordinates the 'whole-of-government' approach to improving the well-being of children and families. Ensuring parents of students with disabilities have clear information about available service delivery models aligns with their mission to expand access to mental health and healthcare services for families.

As an independent state agency providing specialized K-12 education and services to deaf and hard-of-hearing residents, the Maryland School for the Deaf has a direct interest in policies governing special education service delivery models and the coordination between public and private educational placements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing advocates for policies that benefit individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing. A portion of the parentally-placed private school students affected by this bill may fall under their constituency, making the transparency of service delivery models relevant to their advocacy work.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the Maryland Graduate and Professional Scholarship Program by adding the Meritus School of Osteopathic Medicine to the list of eligible institutions where Maryland residents enrolled in specific graduate and professional programs can receive financial assistance.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents enrolled in graduate and professional programs for medicine, dentistry, law, pharmacy, nursing, social work, and veterinary medicine; students attending the Meritus School of Osteopathic Medicine; Maryland institutions of higher education.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not require additional State spending because program funding is provided via the annual State budget, which for fiscal 2026 includes $1.2 million for the program. However, adding a new institution will likely result in decreased funding allocations for currently eligible institutions as the total pool of funds is shared proportionally based on resident enrollment. The Maryland Higher Education Commission can manage administrative changes with existing resources. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC) is the primary agency responsible for establishing, administering, and regulating the Graduate and Professional Scholarship Program, as well as allocating grants to eligible institutions.

The University System of Maryland oversees several schools (including UM Schools of Medicine, Dentistry, Law, Pharmacy, and Social Work) that are primary recipients of these funds; the fiscal note indicates that adding a new school to the fixed budget will decrease the allocations to these existing institutions.
The Department of Budget and Management oversees the annual state budget which funds the Graduate and Professional Scholarship Program ($1.2 million in fiscal 2026).

As a state agency providing graduate education in social work and nursing, Morgan State is an eligible institution for this program and will be impacted by the proportional reallocation of the program's fixed budget.
The Governor's Office drafts the state's annual budget, which includes the specific funding for this scholarship program, and oversees the executive agencies involved in its implementation.

The scholarship program specifically supports students entering fields such as medicine, dentistry, pharmacy, and nursing, which are critical components of the state's healthcare workforce managed and promoted by the Department of Health.
The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the Higher Education Commission and would assist in any regulatory or guideline changes necessitated by the expansion of the scholarship program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) to allow applicants for a driver's license, identification card, or moped operator’s permit to include a 'nonapparent disability' notation on the document. The bill defines nonapparent disabilities to include developmental and intellectual disabilities. It prohibits the MVA from charging a fee for the notation or requiring proof of disability. Additionally, the MVA must conduct public outreach regarding the notation, and the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission must implement training for law enforcement officers on interacting with individuals who have the notation.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA)
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with nonapparent disabilities (including developmental and intellectual disabilities), law enforcement officers, and the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Transportation Trust Fund (TTF) expenditures increase by $75,000 in FY 2026 for one-time vendor costs to update credential templates. Ongoing costs are estimated at $1.39 per credential issued; for every 50,000 individuals requesting the notation, TTF expenditures increase by approximately $69,500. State revenues are not affected because the bill prohibits charging a fee for the notation. The Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission can implement the required training using existing resources. There is no material impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The MVA is the primary agency tasked with implementing the bill's requirements, including updating license and identification card applications, designing the new notation, and executing public outreach efforts.

As the cabinet-level agency overseeing the MVA, MDOT is responsible for the overall administration of vehicle laws and the management of the Transportation Trust Fund, which will cover the bill's implementation costs.

The bill explicitly mandates that the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission consult with the Department of State Police to develop and implement training for officers regarding interactions with individuals who have the nonapparent disability notation.

The department serves as the state's cross-disability policy leader and is a key stakeholder for ensuring that the nonapparent disability notation is accessible and serves the needs of the individuals it advocates for.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The department enhances public safety and oversees standards for law enforcement through bodies like the training commission mentioned in the fiscal note, which is responsible for implementing the bill's mandatory training requirement.
The department promotes the safety of residents with disabilities and coordinates behavioral health initiatives, aligning with the bill’s focus on developmental and intellectual disabilities.
The legislation authorizes the disclosure of nonapparent disability information to the Child Support Administration, which is a major program managed by this department.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch departments implementing the bill and leads initiatives to improve public safety and child well-being, which the bill supports.
The agency's work is directly impacted by the bill’s prohibition on the Motor Vehicle Administration disclosing an applicant’s disability information to the MIA without a court order.
The bill facilitates the disclosure of the new disability notation information to the state's court system, which the AOC manages and supports.
DBM is the state’s central fiscal authority and will oversee the allocation of resources from the Transportation Trust Fund necessary for the MVA to redesign credentials and update its systems.

As the chief legal advisor for state agencies, the OAG will provide guidance on the bill's strict confidentiality requirements and the integration of these new rules with existing state government privacy laws.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Harford County Board of License Commissioners to issue a Class GSF (golf simulator facility) alcoholic beverages license to a holder of one or more Class B licenses. The bill specifies that a Class GSF license must be included in the maximum limit of nine Class B licenses that may be issued to the same person in Harford County.
qa_results.responsible_party: Harford County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Class B alcoholic beverages licensees in Harford County and golf simulator facility operators.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances and does not materially affect Harford County finances or operations. Small business impact is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's chief executive, the Governor's Office is responsible for the final review and signing or vetoing of all legislation passed by the General Assembly, including this bill which modifies the Harford County alcoholic beverages licensing structure.

The Comptroller serves as the state's chief tax collector and fiscal watchdog. As the agency responsible for overseeing business licenses and monitoring state revenues, it has an interest in changes to alcoholic beverage licensing that may affect sales and use tax collections.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the state and is responsible for upholding the rule of law. It would be involved in the legal interpretation and defense of any changes made to the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland.

The Department of Commerce is responsible for stimulating private investment and supporting the expansion of existing companies. This bill creates a new opportunity for business expansion (golf simulator facilities) for existing alcoholic beverages license holders in Harford County.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the laws governing performing arts nonprofit organization alcoholic beverages licenses in Harford County by removing obsolete references to the Maryland Comptroller regarding record-keeping and reporting. It repeals the Comptroller's power to suspend these licenses without a hearing and changes the Harford County Board of License Commissioners' mandate to conduct hearings and impose fines for violations from required to discretionary.
qa_results.responsible_party: Harford County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Performing arts nonprofit organization beer, wine, and liquor license holders in Harford County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect Maryland State or Harford County operations or finances. There are no significant impacts on revenues or expenditures described in the fiscal note.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly repeals outdated references to the Comptroller of Maryland in laws governing alcoholic beverages licenses for performing arts nonprofits in Harford County. It also removes the Comptroller's specific authority to suspend these licenses, reflecting the historical transfer of alcohol enforcement duties from the Comptroller's office to the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission.

The Governor’s Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation. Furthermore, the bill involves the regulatory framework of the executive branch, specifically the transition of authority from the Comptroller to the Executive Director of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission (within the executive department).

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the primary legal advisor to state agencies and the Governor. They are responsible for reviewing legislation for legal sufficiency and advising the Comptroller on their statutory powers and the repeal thereof.

The Department of Commerce is responsible for supporting 'the arts' in Maryland. While the bill is regulatory in nature regarding alcoholic beverages, it specifically affects performing arts nonprofit organizations, which fall under the department's economic and community development interests.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the population-based quota for issuing Class A, Class A-1, and Class A-2 (off-sale) alcoholic beverages licenses in Harford County by increasing the threshold from one license per 4,000 individuals to one license per 4,750 individuals.
qa_results.responsible_party: Harford County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license applicants and current license holders in Harford County, the Harford County Board of License Commissioners, and the residents of Harford County.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state fiscal impact. Locally, the bill does not materially affect Harford County finances or operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the population figures used by the Harford County Board of License Commissioners to determine license quotas to be provided by the Maryland Department of Health, which maintains vital records and demographic data.

The Governor's Office is responsible for signing this legislation into law and overseeing the executive agencies, such as the Department of Health, that provide the data necessary for the bill's implementation.

The Office of the Attorney General acts as the legal advisor to state agencies, including the Department of Health, ensuring that the provision of population data and the interpretation of the new quota law comply with state and federal regulations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the Maryland Statewide Rental Assistance Voucher Program by including the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) as a public housing agency and allowing it to project-base up to 100% of voucher units. It adjusts prioritization for vouchers to include families with children, foster youth, veterans, individuals experiencing homelessness, disabled individuals, and elderly individuals. It also changes unit inspection requirements to at least biennially and increases the administrative funding allocated to local public housing agencies to at least 15% of the program's appropriation.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-income households, families with children, foster youth, veterans, individuals experiencing homelessness, disabled individuals, elderly individuals, and local public housing agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Overall state funding for the program remains unchanged, with a mandated annual appropriation of $10,000,000 through fiscal 2027. Local revenues for public housing agencies will increase because the bill raises the distribution for administrative costs from 6% to the greater of 15% or the federal de minimis rate.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for the Statewide Rental Assistance Voucher Program, DHCD is the central implementing body for this bill. The legislation redefines DHCD as a 'public housing agency,' allows it to project-base its voucher units, and alters its funding distribution for administrative staffing costs.

The bill includes a budgetary mandate requiring the Governor to include a $10 million appropriation for the program in the annual budget through fiscal 2027 and specific levels thereafter. DBM is responsible for formulating the state budget and managing these mandated allocations.

The Governor's Office is responsible for signing the legislation and ensuring the mandated appropriations for the Statewide Rental Assistance Voucher Program are included in the annual budget bill as required by the law.
The bill identifies 'elderly individuals' as one of the specific groups that public housing agencies must prioritize for vouchers and housing assistance payments.
The bill identifies 'disabled individuals' as one of the specific groups that public housing agencies must prioritize for vouchers and housing assistance payments.
The bill identifies 'military veterans' as one of the specific groups that public housing agencies must prioritize for vouchers and housing assistance payments.

The bill prioritizes families with children and foster youth (ages 18-24) for housing vouchers. DHS oversees the state's child welfare and foster care systems and provides economic assistance to vulnerable families.
The bill's prioritization of housing vouchers for families with children and foster youth aligns with the GOC's mission to address childhood poverty and expand support networks for vulnerable youth.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a Land and Property Management Program within the Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR) and authorizes the creation of affiliated foundations to support and promote state parks, forests, and wildlife services. It permits the Governor to transfer funds from the Program Open Space (POS) state land acquisition balance to DNR for operating and maintenance costs when the fund balance exceeds $80 million. Additionally, it mandates that DNR request funding for new staff positions at a specific ratio based on newly acquired land and provides local governments with increased flexibility to use POS funds for development projects once land acquisition goals are met.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland Department of Natural Resources, local governments, state park and forest services, and the general public utilizing state lands and recreation areas.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures are expected to increase by $212,500 in FY 2026, rising to approximately $1,876,000 by FY 2030, primarily to support the new Land and Property Management Program and additional staffing requirements for newly acquired lands. The bill authorizes the use of Program Open Space fund balances to cover these operating expenses if certain financial thresholds are met. Local governments may benefit from greater flexibility in applying POS funds to development projects and simplified matching fund requirements, though total local allocations are not changed.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, the bill establishes a new Land and Property Management Program within DNR, authorizes it to create affiliated foundations, and alters its real property acquisition and staffing requirements.
The bill requires the Board to approve DNR's real property interest acquisitions, execute certain contracts, and approve the new easement valuation systems for conservation interests.
DNR is mandated to submit budget requests to DBM for new permanent staff positions based on specific acreage ratios (1 position per 400 acres) for newly acquired land.

The Governor is authorized to transfer Program Open Space funds to DNR for operating costs and receives mandatory annual reports regarding the operations and staffing of the new affiliated foundations.
The Commission is required to review and approve conflict-of-interest policies for the new affiliated foundations and must be notified of DNR officials serving in dual roles for these foundations.

The Department of Planning is specifically tasked with collaborating with DNR to certify that local jurisdictions have met land acquisition goals, which determines their eligibility for increased development funding under Program Open Space.
The Attorney General is required to review the operating policies of DNR's new affiliated foundations for legal form and sufficiency.
As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller must review and approve DNR's land acquisitions and the expenditure of Program Open Space funds.
As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Treasurer must review and approve DNR's land acquisitions and the expenditure of Program Open Space funds.
DNR is required to consult with DGS to develop a system for appraisal review for its real property acquisitions.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill reestablishes the Maryland Health Insurance Coverage Protection Commission to monitor and assess potential federal changes to health care programs such as the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA), Medicaid, and Medicare. The commission is responsible for recommending state and local actions to protect access to affordable health coverage for Maryland residents.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Department of Legislative Services, the Maryland Department of Health, and the Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents (including seniors and low-income households), healthcare providers, hospitals, managed care organizations, health insurance carriers, employers, and nursing homes.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State agencies (DLS, MDH, and MIA) can likely staff the commission and prepare required reports using existing budgeted resources. The bill has no impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The commission is tasked with monitoring federal changes to Medicare and the ACA, programs that are vital to the Department of Aging's mission to prepare the state for an expanding 60+ population and provide Medicare counseling through SHIP.
The commission monitors changes to the ACA and Medicaid, which are critical for ensuring equal access and community-based living for Marylanders with disabilities, a core mission of this department.

The Department of Health is one of three agencies mandated to staff the commission; its Secretary is a formal member, and it administers Medicaid and the Maryland Children's Health Program, both of which are central to the commission's monitoring duties.

The Department of Human Services is responsible for determining financial eligibility for medical assistance (Medicaid); federal changes to this program monitored by the commission would directly impact the department's operations and its one million constituents.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill establishes a new specialized study group, the Maryland Health Insurance Coverage Protection Commission, to address public health and insurance policy concerns.
The Governor's Office receives the commission's annual report, and the Governor has the authority to appoint several members of the commission representing specific stakeholders.
The Executive Director is a mandated member of the commission, and the body is specifically tasked with monitoring the Maryland All-Payer Model, which the HSCRC regulates.

The Executive Director is a mandated member of the commission, and the body monitors the federal Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA), which the MHBE implements through Maryland Health Connection.
The Insurance Commissioner is a mandated member, and the agency is one of three entities required to provide staff for the commission to monitor health insurance market stability.
