It requires that denial notices include specific bold-print warnings, unique identifiers for decision-makers, and dedicated contact information. Carriers must now report quarterly data aggregated by zip code and provide justifications for significant increases in denial rates. Additionally, private review agents must maintain dedicated telephone and email channels, respond to inquiries within two business days, and make their clinical criteria accessible on their websites.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
qa_results.stakeholders: Health insurance carriers, private review agents, health insurance plan members, and health care providers
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Insurance Administration can implement the bill's requirements using existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Insurance Administration is the primary regulatory agency responsible for overseeing health insurance carriers and private review agents. The bill grants the Insurance Commissioner authority to receive detailed adverse decision reports, conduct examinations based on that data, and enforce new standards for utilization review accessibility.

The bill explicitly requires health insurance carriers to include contact information for the Health Advocacy Unit (a division of the OAG) in all adverse decision and grievance notices to assist consumers with the mediation and appeals process.

The MHBE administers the state's health insurance marketplace. Carriers participating in the exchange must comply with the bill's new notice and reporting requirements for adverse decisions, which directly impacts the consumer experience for marketplace enrollees.

The bill references reporting coordination between the Insurance Commissioner and the Secretary of Health regarding HMO grievance decisions and outcomes, ensuring a integrated regulatory overview of health plan performance.

The Insurance Commissioner is required to provide an annual summary report based on the insurance grievance data collected under this bill to the Governor, who oversees executive branch operations and consumer protection initiatives.

OAH Administrative Law Judges preside over contested health benefit denial cases. The bill's requirements for detailed factual bases and unique identifiers in denial notices will impact the administrative records and proceedings handled by this agency.

Through the Senior Health Insurance Assistance Program (SHIP), the department counsels older adults on insurance issues. The bill's improvements to the clarity and contact information in denial notices will assist counselors in helping seniors navigate the appeals process.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Workgroup on the Creation of a Data Dashboard for Public Work Contracts and Apprentices to study and recommend the most efficient and cost-effective methods for creating a publicly available dashboard. This dashboard is intended to provide disaggregated information on state public work contracts, including details on contractors, subcontractors, employee wages, benefits, and apprentice demographics and certifications. The workgroup is required to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and General Assembly by January 7, 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: Commissioner of Labor and Industry
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland State contractors and subcontractors, employees on public works projects, apprentices, and the Maryland Department of Labor.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of Labor can staff the workgroup using existing resources. Any expense reimbursements for workgroup members are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing resources. The bill has no effect on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes a workgroup to study public work contracts and apprenticeships, and specifically mandates that the Secretary of Labor and the Commissioner of Labor and Industry serve on the workgroup. Furthermore, the Department of Labor is tasked with providing the necessary staffing for the workgroup and currently administers the prevailing wage and apprenticeship programs that are the subject of the study.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a specialized 'Workgroup on the Creation of a Data Dashboard for Public Work Contracts and Apprentices' to conduct a study and provide policy recommendations to the Governor and General Assembly, which aligns with the functional description of this entity category.

The Governor is responsible for appointing several members to the workgroup representing various trade associations and minority contractor organizations. Additionally, the workgroup must report its findings and recommendations directly to the Governor by January 2027.

DGS is the central agency responsible for the design, construction, and maintenance of state-owned facilities. As a primary manager of public work contracts, the agency's procurement data and processes will be central to the workgroup's study of a data dashboard.

MDOT manages a massive multi-modal transportation network and is a major issuer of public work contracts in Maryland. The fiscal note explicitly lists MDOT as a source of information for this legislation, indicating their data would be relevant to the proposed dashboard.

The Board of Public Works approves significant state procurement contracts and public work expenditures. The proposed dashboard aims to increase transparency regarding the very contracts and apprenticeship requirements that fall under the BPW's administrative oversight.

The IAC oversees the construction and renovation of public school facilities, which are major 'public works' as defined by state law. Projects funded through the IAC are subject to prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements that would be tracked by the proposed data dashboard.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the workgroup to include a representative from the Maryland Minority Contractors Association and to study the disaggregation of data regarding public work contracts. This oversight of diverse business participation in state-funded infrastructure is a core mission of this office.

The board is responsible for state policy regarding the workforce system and creating pathways to employment. The bill’s focus on apprenticeship data, demographics, and certification directly relates to the board’s mission to monitor the effectiveness of vocational training and career pipelines.

The USM is a major state entity that executes public work contracts. Although currently exempt from some prevailing wage laws, the fiscal note indicates they voluntarily comply with these standards, meaning their contracts and apprentices would likely be within the scope of the workgroup's study.

Morgan State University is identified in the bill's fiscal note as a state entity that executes public work contracts and voluntarily complies with prevailing wage and apprenticeship standards, making their data relevant to the dashboard study.

As a public institution that manages its own construction and infrastructure projects, the college is part of the broader conversation regarding public work contract transparency and apprenticeship participation outlined in the bill's appendix.

The MSA plans and manages the construction of world-class sports, entertainment, and educational facilities. These projects represent significant public work contracts that would be scrutinized under the proposed transparency dashboard.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Maryland Second Look Act expands postconviction review by allowing individuals who committed a crime between the ages of 18 and 24 to petition a court to reduce their sentence after serving at least 20 years of confinement. The bill excludes sex offenders, those sentenced to life without the possibility of parole, and individuals convicted of murdering a first responder in the line of duty. It establishes specific criteria for courts to consider, such as the individual's rehabilitation and maturity, and includes various protections and participation rights for victims.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and the Office of the Public Defender
qa_results.stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals who committed offenses between ages 18 and 24, crime victims and their representatives, the Office of the Public Defender, State's Attorneys' offices, and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by at least $538,100 in FY 2026 for the Office of the Public Defender to hire additional staff (attorneys, a social worker, and administrative personnel) to handle the projected caseload. These costs are expected to rise to approximately $730,300 by FY 2030. Conversely, general fund expenditures for the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services will decrease by an indeterminate amount if the bill leads to the earlier release of incarcerated individuals. Local State's Attorneys' offices may experience a minimal increase in expenditures to handle new petitions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes new judicial procedures, hearing requirements, and decision-making criteria for Maryland circuit courts regarding motions to reduce sentences for a specific demographic of incarcerated individuals.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS is responsible for the management of the incarcerated population and will be directly affected by the potential release of individuals under this act, which also impacts facility operations and community supervision.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note identifies a significant expenditure increase for OPD to provide legal representation and social work support for eligible individuals filing motions under this act.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP manages public safety policy and victim services, which are critical components of the bill, particularly regarding victim notification and the newly established victim protection procedures.

DBM oversees the state's personnel and operating budgets, both of which are impacted by the projected staffing costs for the Office of the Public Defender and potential variable cost savings for DPSCS.

As the chief legal advisor for the state, the OAG may provide guidance on the interpretation of this act and represent the state's interests in any subsequent criminal appeals related to sentence reductions.
The Governor's Office is responsible for signing the legislation and overseeing the executive agencies (DPSCS, GOCPP, and OPD) that must implement the policy and fiscal changes mandated by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the membership of the Workgroup on Establishing a Science and Technology Best Practices and Innovation Network and extends its termination date and reporting deadline. Specifically, it reduces the number of representatives from certain sectors and extends the workgroup's existence for two additional years to allow for the completion of its findings and recommendations regarding an open-access science and innovation network.
qa_results.responsible_party: University of Maryland, Baltimore County
qa_results.stakeholders: Citizen scientists and experts in science, technology, and industry; institutions of higher education (including historically Black colleges and universities, independent institutions, and community colleges); and private and nonprofit sector entities in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State revenues. Expenditures are not significantly impacted as the University of Maryland, Baltimore County can staff the workgroup for two additional years using existing budgeted resources. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Governor to appoint a significant portion of the workgroup's members, including those with expertise in science/technology and representatives from various higher education segments. Additionally, the workgroup must submit its final report to the Governor.
The bill explicitly names the Executive Director of the Maryland Technology Development Corporation (TEDCO), or their designee, as a required member of the workgroup.
The bill mandates that the University of Maryland Baltimore County (UMBC) provide staff for the workgroup. UMBC is a constituent institution of the University System of Maryland.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill directly concerns the composition, duration, and reporting requirements of a state workgroup, which is the type of specialized study group defined under this executive branch category.

The Office of Appointments is responsible for vetting candidates for the Governor's appointments to various boards and commissions; this bill specifically alters and requires new appointments for specialized science and technology experts.

The bill requires a representative from a historically Black college or university (HBCU) with expertise in science or technology research. Morgan State is a primary state HBCU and is designated as the state's preeminent urban research university.

The workgroup includes representatives from community colleges, independent institutions, and HBCUs. MHEC is the regulatory and coordinating board for these institutional segments and their science/technology programs.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes a person who is licensed or authorized to hunt deer and who wounds a deer during legal hunting hours to pursue and kill that deer after legal hunting hours. It permits the use of artificial lights, such as spotlights or headlights, during the pursuit, provided the hunter uses only the weapons authorized for the current hunting season or permit.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Deer hunters in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect State or local finances. The Department of Natural Resources is required to adopt regulations to implement the bill, but no fiscal impact is anticipated for revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Natural Resources (DNR) is the primary agency responsible for regulating hunting in Maryland. The bill specifically authorizes DNR to manage deer hunting hours and methods, and it mandates that the Department adopt new regulations to implement the pursuit and killing of wounded deer using lights after legal hours.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the primary legal advisor to state agencies, including the Department of Natural Resources. They will be responsible for providing legal counsel and reviewing the new regulations required by the bill for legal sufficiency and compliance with existing statutes.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the operations of the Department of Natural Resources. The Governor also signed this bill into law, and the office ensures that the executive branch properly enforces the new hunting authorizations.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange (MHBE), in collaboration with the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE), to promote health insurance access for child care professionals. It mandates MHBE to partner with child care associations and nonprofit organizations, provide outreach and enrollment assistance for Medicaid and private health plans, and conduct a survey to assess the current levels of health insurance coverage and needs within the child care provider community.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange
qa_results.stakeholders: Child care professionals, child care employers, child care associations, and prekindergarten provider hubs.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures increase by $250,000 in FY 2026 as funds are transferred from the Department of Commerce to the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to conduct the required outreach and survey. MSDE can implement its partnership duties with existing resources. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies involved in this bill (MSDE, Commerce, and MDH) and is responsible for signing the legislation and managing the annual budget, which includes the contingent fund transfer for the program's implementation.

DBM is responsible for the state's central fiscal and personnel authority, including the budget amendment process required to transfer funds from the Department of Commerce to the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange as specified in the fiscal note.

The bill has a direct fiscal impact on the Department of Commerce, as $250,000 is transferred from its Child Care Capital Support Revolving Loan Fund to support the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange's outreach and survey efforts.

MSDE is a primary partner in the bill's mandate, required to collaborate with the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange on health insurance outreach and the development of a survey for child care professionals and prekindergarten provider hubs.

The bill requires the Exchange to help child care professionals obtain Medicaid and assist those losing Medicaid coverage with alternative options, which directly relates to the Department of Health's responsibility for administering the state's Medicaid program.

The Maryland Health Benefit Exchange is the primary implementing agency tasked with promoting health insurance access, conducting a targeted outreach campaign, and administering a survey to assess healthcare access within the child care community.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits common carriers and their employees from damaging public infrastructure, specifically bridges or highways, in a way that necessitates its closure. Such damage is classified as a public nuisance, allowing the State or local governments to file civil actions for injunctive relief, declaratory relief, compensatory damages for repair/replacement, and civil penalties of $1,000 per day until the infrastructure is repaired or replaced.
qa_results.responsible_party: The State of Maryland (Office of the Attorney General/MDOT) and local governments
qa_results.stakeholders: Common carriers (including motor vehicle, railroad, taxicab, transit, and transportation network companies), their employees, the Maryland Department of Transportation (MDOT), the Maryland Transportation Authority (MDTA), and local governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund and local revenues may increase from daily civil penalties ($1,000/day). Transportation Trust Fund (TTF) and local finances may see positive impacts from recovered compensatory damages for infrastructure repair. State and local expenditures may increase minimally to cover litigation costs and the retention of legal counsel.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDOT is the primary state agency responsible for the planning, maintenance, and operation of the state's transportation network. The bill directly impacts MDOT as it protects 'public infrastructure' (bridges and highways) which MDOT and its business units own and maintain. MDOT will likely be the primary plaintiff in civil actions to recover damages for infrastructure repair.

As the unit of MDOT responsible for the maintenance and construction of state-numbered highways and all non-tolled bridges, SHA is the direct steward of a significant portion of the 'public infrastructure' defined in the bill. They would be the entity identifying damage and necessitating infrastructure closures.

MDTA is explicitly mentioned in the fiscal note as a likely entity to engage in litigation under this bill to recover costs for repairs to tolled facilities (such as major bridges and tunnels) damaged by common carriers.

The OAG serves as the legal representative for the State and its agencies. They would be responsible for bringing civil actions against common carriers for public nuisance and seeking compensatory damages and penalties on behalf of MDOT, SHA, or MDTA.

The bill creates a new specific cause of action for a public nuisance in the court system. The AOC is responsible for the administrative and technological infrastructure of the courts that will process these new civil filings and proceedings.

The PSC regulates many of the 'common carriers' defined in the bill, including taxicab companies and motor bus (charter) companies. The establishment of infrastructure damage as a 'public nuisance' for these carriers may have regulatory implications or involve PSC data and licensing records.

MSP enforces motor vehicle laws and investigates major accidents on state highways. Their investigation reports and findings would serve as critical evidence in civil actions brought by the state to prove a common carrier caused infrastructure damage.

As the state's chief financial officer, the Comptroller oversees the collection of state revenues. Penalties recovered under this bill ($1,000 per day) would likely be processed through the Comptroller's office for the General Fund.

The Treasurer's Office manages the state's risk and insurance programs. While this bill focuses on civil litigation for damages, the Treasurer also sits on the Board of Public Works which may review large contracts for infrastructure repairs funded by recovered damages.

DBM oversees the state's fiscal health and budget allocation. The fiscal note indicates potential increases in General Fund revenues and impacts on the Transportation Trust Fund, both of which fall under DBM's budgetary monitoring and revenue estimation duties.

Significant repair or replacement of bridges and highways (exceeding certain procurement thresholds) requires approval from the Board of Public Works. The funds recovered via these lawsuits would likely be used for such BPW-approved capital improvements.
The Governor’s Office is the principal executive agency that signed the bill into law and oversees the agencies (MDOT, OAG, MSP) tasked with its implementation and enforcement.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires transportation network companies (TNCs) to provide their drivers with weekly summaries of their fares and earnings, including a breakdown of fees and the percentage of total fares earned by the driver. It also requires TNCs to submit annual reports to the Public Service Commission containing aggregated data on average fares, total hours driven, and total driver earnings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Public Service Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Transportation network companies (such as Uber and Lyft), transportation network operators (drivers), and the Maryland Public Service Commission.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Public Service Commission can implement the bill using existing budgeted resources. State revenues are not affected, and there is no fiscal impact on local governments. The impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal or none, as most TNCs are not small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Service Commission is the primary regulatory agency for the bill. It is responsible for collecting annual data from transportation network companies (TNCs), determining the format for demographic data, and compiling these reports for the General Assembly and the Department of Transportation.
The bill explicitly requires the Public Service Commission to report the compiled TNC data and earnings summaries to the Department of Transportation on or before March 1 each year.

As the primary legal advisor to state agencies, the Office of the Attorney General will likely be responsible for advising the Public Service Commission on the implementation of these new regulatory requirements, particularly regarding the protection of trade secrets and confidential information.

The Governor signed the bill into law and oversees the Public Service Commission (an independent unit) and the Department of Transportation, ensuring the coordination and execution of the reporting mandates.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows the Governor to transfer funds from the Catastrophic Event Account to the State Disaster Recovery Fund when the fund's balance is depleted or when estimated disaster relief costs exceed the available balance. It also shortens the review and comment period for the Legislative Policy Committee from 15 days to 10 days for budget amendments related to fund transfers from the Catastrophic Event Account.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor, Department of Budget and Management (DBM), and Maryland Department of Emergency Management (MDEM)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland State agencies, local governments, and residents or entities affected by natural disasters or catastrophic events.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no net effect on State finances as it only authorizes the transfer of existing funds between accounts. If a transfer occurs, special fund expenditures for the Catastrophic Event Account increase and special fund revenues for the State Disaster Recovery Fund increase by the same amount. There may be a minimal decrease in interest revenue for the Revenue Stabilization Account (Rainy Day Fund). State and local governments may benefit from a faster fund transfer process due to the reduced legislative review period.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor is the primary authority granted power by this bill to transfer funds between disaster accounts via budget amendment and manage the state's emergency fiscal response.
DBM administers the Catastrophic Event Account and oversees the budget amendment process for the fund transfers and revised review timelines authorized by this bill.
MDEM manages the State Disaster Recovery Fund, which is the primary recipient of the fund transfers authorized to support disaster relief when federal declarations are absent.
The bill explicitly tasks the Comptroller with the accounting responsibilities for the Catastrophic Event Account funds.
The bill explicitly tasks the State Treasurer with holding and investing the funds within the Catastrophic Event Account.
As the agency responsible for state highways and critical infrastructure, MDOT is a primary end-user of disaster recovery funds for emergency repairs facilitated by this bill.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Governor and state agencies regarding the implementation of emergency fund transfers and compliance with the Public Safety and State Finance articles.
DGS manages state-owned facilities and infrastructure that may require emergency funding from these accounts for repairs following catastrophic events or disasters.
DNR is a potential recipient of disaster recovery funds for responding to and mitigating natural disasters affecting the state's public lands and waterways.
MDE is a potential recipient of disaster recovery funds for managing environmental emergencies and public health hazards resulting from catastrophic events.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a Class C (theater) beer, wine, and liquor license in Frederick County, allowing theaters with seating to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption during a window of one hour before to one hour after performances, fundraisers, or private rental events.
qa_results.responsible_party: Frederick County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Theater owners and managers in Frederick County, patrons of Frederick County theaters, and the Frederick County Board of License Commissioners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no impact on State finances. Frederick County revenues will increase starting in fiscal 2026 based on the number of $150 annual license fees collected. Any additional enforcement activity by the county can be managed with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation passed by the General Assembly; this bill was approved and signed by the Governor on May 20, 2025.

The Comptroller serves as the state's tax collector and fiscal watchdog. While the fiscal note indicates no immediate state effect, the creation of a new alcoholic beverages license class involves the sale of products subject to state sales and excise taxes which the Comptroller oversees.

The Department of Commerce is responsible for stimulating economic development and supporting diverse sectors including the arts. This bill establishes a new liquor license for theaters in Frederick County, supporting the economic viability of small businesses in the arts and entertainment sector.

The MOTD promotes Maryland as a premier travel destination and supports tourism-related infrastructure. The expansion of services at Frederick County theaters to include beer, wine, and liquor enhances the visitor experience and the competitiveness of local cultural destinations.

The State Archives is the central depository for legislative records and manages the Maryland Manual On-Line. This bill modifies the Annotated Code regarding local board authorities, which must be documented and updated within the state's historical and administrative records.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Preserve Telehealth Access Act of 2025 makes permanent the inclusion of audio-only telephone conversations in the definition of telehealth and requires that both the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid) and private insurance carriers reimburse telehealth services at the same rate as in-person services. The bill also allows health care practitioners to prescribe Schedule II opiates for pain via telehealth if a bona fide patient-practitioner relationship exists and a previous in-person assessment was conducted, and it mandates that the Maryland Health Care Commission submit a report on telehealth developments every four years.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Care Commission, Maryland Department of Health, and Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Health care patients, medical practitioners, health insurance carriers, nonprofit health service plans, health maintenance organizations, and the Maryland Medical Assistance Program
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill increases Maryland Health Care Commission special fund expenditures by an estimated $100,000 in FY 2027 and every four years thereafter for mandated reporting. By making telehealth reimbursement parity and audio-only coverage permanent, Medicaid and federal fund revenues and expenditures will continue beyond the previous FY 2025 sunset. Maryland Insurance Administration special fund revenues will decrease minimally in FY 2026 due to filing fees. Local government expenditures may increase to maintain telehealth coverage for employee health benefits.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Maryland Health Care Commission to submit a quadrennial report on telehealth advances and costs directly to the Governor. The office also oversees the executive agencies responsible for implementing the bill's provisions.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Health and the Maryland Insurance Administration. They would provide counsel on the implementation of the new telehealth reimbursement laws and regulatory changes regarding the prescription of controlled substances.

As the advocate for older adults, this agency is impacted by telehealth policies, as many seniors rely on telehealth (specifically audio-only modalities addressed in the bill) for healthcare access and Medicare/Medicaid-related services.

DBM manages the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. While the fiscal note suggests no material impact, any changes to telehealth reimbursement parity laws affect the cost and structure of state-funded health insurance plans.

The agency coordinates cross-disability policy. Telehealth is a critical component of accessible healthcare for individuals with disabilities, and the bill's expansion of audio-only services and reimbursement parity directly affects their constituent base.

MDH is a primary implementing agency as it oversees the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid). The bill mandates permanent reimbursement for telehealth on the same basis and rate as in-person care for Medicaid providers.

The bill explicitly states that its provisions do not supersede the authority of the HSCRC to set hospital rates, including facility fees for hospital-provided telehealth, requiring coordination between the commission and the bill's requirements.

MHBE administers Maryland Health Connection. The bill's requirements for commercial insurers to provide telehealth coverage and reimbursement parity will directly affect the health and dental plans offered on the state's official marketplace.
The bill mandates that the MHCC submit a detailed report to the Governor and General Assembly every four years regarding advances in telehealth delivery, costs, and findings, beginning in 2026.

The MIA is responsible for regulating commercial insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and HMOs. It must ensure that these entities comply with the bill's mandates for telehealth coverage and reimbursement parity.

The bill alters the circumstances under which healthcare practitioners may prescribe Schedule II opiates for pain via telehealth. OCSA, which enforces the state's Controlled Dangerous Substances Act, is responsible for monitoring these regulatory changes.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the definition of a hospital 'community benefit' to include community health worker (CHW) workforce programs established through partnerships between nonprofit hospitals and community-based organizations. It outlines the primary purpose of such programs as improving health outcomes and addressing social determinants of health, and it provides framework requirements for partnerships, including a memorandum of understanding covering program design, data standards, and responsibilities for recruitment, training, and health insurance for workers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Health Services Cost Review Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland nonprofit hospitals, community-based organizations, community health workers, and hospital patients.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect state or local governmental operations or finances. It permits nonprofit hospitals to count expenditures for community health worker workforce programs toward their community benefit reporting requirements. There is no impact on small businesses or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill directly impacts the Health Services Cost Review Commission (HSCRC) as it alters the definition of 'community benefit' which hospitals must report to the Commission. The HSCRC is the primary regulatory body responsible for overseeing hospital community benefit financial reports and ensuring hospital expenditures align with identified community health needs.

The Department of Health (MDH) is the parent agency of the HSCRC and is responsible for the certification and accreditation of training programs for Community Health Workers (CHWs). As the bill facilitates the expansion of the CHW workforce through hospital programs, MDH's role in health policy and workforce certification is highly relevant.

The bill includes provisions authorizing CHW workforce programs to provide health insurance coverage to workers who lack it. The MIA is responsible for regulating health insurance products and ensuring compliance with state and federal insurance laws, making it relevant to the insurance-related components of the program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill clarifies that liability for failing to comply with a tenant's right of first refusal to purchase a residential property is restricted to the property owner and does not attach to the property itself when the property is sold to a third party.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential tenants, residential property owners (landlords), and third-party purchasers of residential rental property.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not affect State or local government finances or operations. There are no estimated revenues or expenditures associated with this legislation.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mentions the Secretary (of Housing and Community Development) as the authority responsible for establishing regulations and specifying notice forms. Furthermore, the Department's Office of Tenant and Landlord Affairs (OTLA) is the primary recipient of the mandatory notices required for a tenant's right of first refusal and is responsible for managing related documentation.

The bill clarifies civil liability and the attachment of claims to residential property titles following a breach of statutory requirements. As the administrative lead for the state's judicial system, the AOC is relevant as these changes directly impact property law litigation and title-related disputes adjudicated in Maryland courts.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the deadlines for the Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission to submit its interim and final reports and extends the commission's termination date from June 30, 2026, to June 30, 2029.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy (GOCPP)
qa_results.stakeholders: Adult offenders in the Maryland criminal justice system, the Maryland General Assembly, and the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures are projected to increase by a total of $204,600 between FY 2026 and FY 2029 to maintain a contractual program coordinator position to support the commission. Specifically, costs are estimated at $28,500 in FY 2026, $65,600 in FY 2027, $68,400 in FY 2028, and $42,100 in FY 2029. The bill has no effect on state revenues or local government operations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is the primary staffing entity for the Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission. The bill's extension of the commission directly impacts GOCPP's operations and budget, as noted in the fiscal note regarding contractual staff funding.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly concerns the timeline and reporting requirements for the Prison Education Delivery Reform Commission, which falls under this category of executive-branch study groups.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The commission's primary mandate is to reform education delivery within the state's prison system, which is managed and operated by DPSCS. The policies developed will directly affect their rehabilitation and vocational initiatives.

The commission is tasked with researching best practices for education for individuals subject to the juvenile justice system, making its findings and policy frameworks highly relevant to DJS's mission.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office receives the commission's interim and final reports and oversees the strategic goals regarding public safety and recidivism reduction addressed by the commission.

The commission is required to evaluate the effectiveness of current workforce programs, which are primary responsibilities of the Department of Labor's workforce development and apprenticeship divisions.

The commission researches best practices for primary and secondary education for justice-involved individuals, overlapping with MSDE's oversight of statewide educational standards and vocational rehabilitation.
The commission's mandate includes researching postsecondary education options for adult offenders, which falls under MHEC's coordination of the state's colleges and universities.
DBM is impacted due to the bill's requirement for general fund expenditures to maintain contractual staff for the commission through FY 2029.

The commission is required to use a data-driven approach to research education and workforce outcomes, work that directly correlates with the linked student and workforce data maintained by the MLDS Center.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Task Force to Improve Attendance and Reduce Chronic Absenteeism in Schools to study, analyze data, and make recommendations on strategies to identify and prevent student chronic absenteeism. The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) is tasked with staffing the force, updating attendance regulations based on its recommendations, and distributing a toolkit and guidance to local school systems.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland public school students, parents, teachers, school administrators, local school systems, and educational organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures are not impacted as MSDE can staff the task force and update regulations using existing budgeted resources. State revenues are not affected. Local school operations may be affected by new regulations, but local finances are not expected to be materially impacted.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's primary agency for public K-12 education, the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) is the lead implementer of this bill. The agency is responsible for staffing the task force, appointing its members, updating student attendance regulations based on task force recommendations, and distributing the resulting toolkits and guidance to local school systems.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a specialized Task Force to Improve Attendance and Reduce Chronic Absenteeism in Schools, which falls under this functional category of executive study groups authorized to address specific policy issues and provide recommendations to the Governor and General Assembly.

The Governor's Office is mandated to have a direct representative on the task force and is the primary recipient of the final report, findings, and recommendations regarding student attendance policy.

Chronic absenteeism is a key performance indicator for this office, which leads a 'whole-of-government' approach to improving child well-being and eliminating childhood poverty. The task force's findings will directly inform their strategies for neighborhood-based interventions and educational success.

The agency is responsible for maintaining the state's linked student data and analyzing educational program effectiveness. The task force's mandate to analyze student attendance data collection practices and trends directly overlaps with the MLDS Center's analytical mission.

The task force must include a school-based public health professional or clinical social worker. Given the agency's oversight of public health, school-based health centers, and behavioral health services, the task force's recommendations on prevention and intervention strategies for absenteeism are relevant to their work.

The task force requires representation from an institution of higher education. As the state’s coordinating board for colleges and universities, MHEC is relevant to the selection and policy alignment of this higher education perspective within K-12 attendance strategies.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill phases in a requirement that all child support collected on behalf of families receiving assistance through the Family Investment Program (FIP) must pass through directly to the family and be disregarded when calculating their assistance amount. The pass-through requirement increases annually starting in fiscal year 2028, reaching 100% of collected child support by fiscal year 2031.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Families receiving Temporary Cash Assistance (TCA) through the Family Investment Program (FIP) who are entitled to child support payments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no fiscal impact in FY 2026. In FY 2027, general and federal fund expenditures increase by $406,100 for required technology upgrades. Starting in FY 2028, general fund expenditures increase as the State must replace lost special fund revenue (from child support collections previously retained) and reimburse the federal government for its share of collections. This cost is estimated at $2.4 million in FY 2028, rising to $13.9 million annually beginning in FY 2031. Local government finances are not materially impacted.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DHS is the primary implementing agency. Its Family Investment Administration (FIA) manages the Family Investment Program (FIP) and Temporary Cash Assistance (TCA), while its Child Support Administration (CSA) manages the collection and pass-through of support payments affected by this bill.

The bill has a significant fiscal impact, requiring an increase in general fund expenditures of $13.9 million annually by FY 2031 to offset the loss of child support revenues and reimburse the federal government. DBM is responsible for drafting the state budget and managing these fiscal allocations.

This agency leads the state's efforts to eliminate childhood poverty. The bill directly supports this mission by increasing the amount of child support income available to low-income families with children without reducing their state assistance.

The Innovation Team's central focus is reducing childhood poverty and increasing economic mobility. This bill acts as a direct policy intervention to improve economic outcomes for vulnerable families, aligning with the team's data-driven priority initiatives.

As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the policy direction of the Family Investment Program and the drafting of the annual budget which must now account for the millions in lost child support offsets.

The fiscal note identifies a need for one-time technology upgrades costing over $400,000 to the Child Support Management System and the Eligibility and Enrollment System to handle the new pass-through and disregard logic, which falls under DoIT's strategic oversight.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows individuals who were members of the State Police Retirement System, the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System, or the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System on or before June 30, 2011, to maintain their original benefit structure upon returning to service after a break. To qualify, the individual must have been separated from employment for four years or less, been on qualifying military leave, or have been vested at the time of separation without withdrawing their contributions.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Retirement Agency
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of the State Police Retirement System (SPRS), Correctional Officers’ Retirement System (CORS), and Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System (LEOPS) who were employed prior to July 2011; participating local government units.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no discernible effect on State or local retirement liabilities or contribution rates. The State Retirement Agency identified only 16 members of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System who would benefit, and no eligible members in the other systems. There is no impact on State or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Retirement Agency is the primary administrative arm of the State Retirement and Pension System and is responsible for the three specific systems modified by the bill: the State Police Retirement System, the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System, and the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System. They must identify and process returning members who qualify for the pre-2011 benefit structures.

The bill directly affects the State Police Retirement System (SPRS), which is the primary retirement plan for Maryland State Police officers. The bill allows returning MSP members to resume their prior benefit structures under certain conditions.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly affects the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System (CORS), which covers the majority of the department's correctional workforce. This change impacts the retirement benefits and recruitment/retention of returning personnel within this system.

MDOT employs law enforcement officers through the MDTA Police and the Maryland Port Administration who are members of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System (LEOPS), which is one of the systems modified by the bill.

DNR employs the Natural Resources Police, who are participants in the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System (LEOPS). The bill allows eligible returning officers to remain in the more favorable pre-2011 benefit structure.

As the state's central personnel authority, DBM manages the statewide personnel system and oversees the fiscal implications of employee benefits, including changes to retirement tiers for returning state employees.
DGS manages the Maryland Capitol Police, whose officers are members of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System (LEOPS) impacted by this legislation.

Certain personnel within the Department of Juvenile Services are members of the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System (CORS) or LEOPS and are therefore affected by the bill's provisions regarding return to service.

Campus police officers across the University System of Maryland are members of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System (LEOPS) and may be affected by the changes if they return to service after a break.
Morgan State University campus police officers are members of the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System (LEOPS), which is directly addressed in the bill.

The Comptroller's Office employs field agents and investigative staff who are members of LEOPS; additionally, the office manages the state's central payroll and sits on the Board of Public Works which has fiscal oversight of state funds.

The State Treasurer's Office provides administrative oversight for the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System through the Treasurer's seat on its Board of Trustees and the Board of Public Works.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Maryland State Retirement Agency and executive departments on the interpretation and implementation of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.
OLA conducts fiscal and compliance audits of the State Retirement Agency and would be responsible for ensuring that the agency correctly applies the new return-to-service rules.
As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees all impacted departments and signed this legislation into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill modifies the qualifications for certified public accountants (CPAs) licensed in other states to practice in Maryland. It repeals the requirement that the National Association of State Boards of Accountancy (NASBA) verify that a state's licensure requirements are equivalent to the Uniform Accountancy Act, instead requiring that the individual has passed the Uniform CPA Examination and holds a valid license from another state.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Public Accountancy
qa_results.stakeholders: Out-of-state licensed certified public accountants (CPAs), the State Board of Public Accountancy, and accounting firms employing out-of-state practitioners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The State Board of Public Accountancy can implement the bill's changes using existing resources. Special fund revenues and expenditures are likely not materially affected. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Labor, through the State Board of Public Accountancy, is the primary agency responsible for the licensing and regulation of certified public accountants (CPAs) in Maryland. This bill directly alters the qualifications and requirements for out-of-state CPAs to exercise practice privileges in the state, which is a core regulatory function of the department.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the legal advisor to state agencies, including the Department of Labor. They would be responsible for providing legal counsel regarding the implementation of the bill's changes to reciprocity and practice privilege standards and would represent the State Board of Public Accountancy in legal matters related to these new requirements.

As the chief executive office, the Governor oversees all state departments, including the Department of Labor. The office is responsible for signing the legislation into law and ensuring that executive agencies properly enforce the revised qualifications for out-of-state practice privileges.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the qualifications for an initial teacher certificate by allowing applicants to pass a portfolio-based assessment from a nationally accredited teacher preparation program to satisfy certification requirements.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals who have graduated from a teacher preparation program or an alternative teacher preparation program, prospective teachers, and local Maryland school systems.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Expanding options for graduates to qualify for a teaching certificate through a portfolio-based assessment has no material fiscal effect on State or local finances. Local school systems may benefit from an increased availability of licensed teachers.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) is the primary agency responsible for teacher certification and licensing. This bill directly alters the statutory qualifications MSDE must use to issue an initial teacher certificate.

The University System of Maryland oversees multiple universities with nationally accredited teacher preparation programs. The bill allows portfolio-based assessments conducted within these programs to satisfy state certification requirements for their graduates.

As a state agency and university with a teacher preparation program, Morgan State's program assessments are directly impacted by this legislation, which now recognizes their portfolio-based assessments for initial state certification.

As the state's public honors college, Saint Mary's offers teacher preparation. The bill expands the pathways for its graduates to qualify for initial teacher certification through the college's accredited program assessments.

MHEC is responsible for establishing statewide policies and long-range planning for Maryland's colleges and universities, including the approval of academic programs like the teacher preparation programs referenced in the bill.

The OAG serves as the legal advisor to the Department of Education and the State Board of Education. They will be responsible for providing legal counsel regarding the implementation of these new certification standards and related regulatory changes.

The Governor's Office oversees the operations of all state departments, including MSDE, and is responsible for signing the legislation into law and overseeing the general executive policy regarding teacher recruitment and workforce development.

The MLDS Center tracks the transition from education to the workforce. Changes in teacher certification requirements may impact the data they collect and analyze regarding teacher preparation outcomes and workforce entry.

The GWDB is responsible for creating pathways to employment in high-demand fields. While MSDE manages the licensing, the GWDB has a strategic interest in policy changes that affect the pipeline of qualified teachers in the state.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the administrative penalties for oyster authorization violations by changing the penalty for a first offense from revocation to suspension for up to five years. It maintains revocation for second or subsequent offenses and provides a process for the reinstatement of authorizations revoked before July 1, 2025, after a five-year period. Additionally, the bill modifies the definition of a prohibited gear violation, removes the 90-day deadline for administrative hearings, and prohibits individuals from working in the oyster fishery while their authorization is suspended or revoked.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Commercial oyster harvesters, tidal fish license holders, individuals on the commercial license waiting list, and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $5,290 and special fund expenditures increase by $6,210 annually beginning in FY 2026 due to the costs of additional administrative hearings. Special fund revenues may decrease minimally as suspended authorizations are held rather than being revoked and reallocated. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Natural Resources (DNR) is the primary agency responsible for implementing and enforcing the bill. It manages tidal fish licenses, issues oyster authorizations, and is tasked with administering the new suspension and reinstatement procedures established by the legislation.

The bill and fiscal note explicitly state that administrative hearings for oyster authorization penalties must be conducted in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act. The fiscal note anticipates an increase in the number of hearings handled by the Office of Administrative Hearings and identifies a corresponding increase in state expenditures to fund these proceedings.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the legal advisor and representative for the Department of Natural Resources. They would be responsible for providing counsel during the administrative hearings and representing the state in any judicial reviews resulting from penalty decisions.

The bill provides for judicial review of DNR's final decisions in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act. This involves the state court system, which is supported by the Administrative Office of the Courts.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for overseeing the state's budget. The fiscal note indicates an annual increase in general and special fund expenditures due to increased hearing costs, which directly impacts the fiscal planning managed by this agency.

The bill impacts commercial fishing licenses, and the fiscal note identifies a potential meaningful impact on small businesses. As the state's primary agency for economic development and small business support, the Department of Commerce is relevant to the economic welfare of the impacted industry members.

The Governor's Office oversees the Department of Natural Resources and the execution of state laws. The Governor signed the bill, which dictates administrative policy for state-regulated natural resources.

The Office of Legislative Audits conducts fiscal and performance audits of executive agencies like the DNR. They would monitor the administrative compliance of the new reinstatement and penalty structures to ensure they are handled according to the revised state law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Secretary of Natural Resources to issue permits for the incidental taking of four specific bat species—the Indiana bat, the northern long-eared bat, the tricolored bat, and the eastern small-footed bat—provided that the applicant submits a detailed conservation plan and the Secretary makes specific findings regarding the survival of the species and mitigation efforts. It requires applicants to have obtained federal authorization for the taking where applicable.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Small businesses subject to seasonal or environmental restrictions in bat habitats, property developers, the Department of Natural Resources, and specific bat populations (Indiana, northern long-eared, tricolored, and eastern small-footed bats).
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State or local finances or operations. It may have a meaningful impact on small businesses by allowing them to bypass certain time-of-year or activity restrictions through the incidental taking permit process, provided they meet conservation and mitigation requirements.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Natural Resources is the primary agency responsible for the bill's implementation. The Secretary of Natural Resources is granted the specific authority to issue incidental taking permits for the named bat species, review required conservation plans, and make necessary findings regarding the species' survival and recovery.

As the chief executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Natural Resources. The Governor signed this legislation into law, and the office is responsible for the broader executive policy framework regarding environmental protection and species conservation.

The OAG acts as the legal advisor to the Department of Natural Resources. It would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the permitting process, the validity of the conservation plans, and the drafting of any new regulations authorized under the bill.

The fiscal note indicates a potential meaningful impact on small businesses that face time-of-year or habitat-related restrictions. By establishing an incidental taking permit, the bill may facilitate economic development and private investment by allowing certain projects to proceed under approved conservation plans.

Bats play a critical role in agricultural pest control. Policies affecting the conservation and taking of endangered bat species have potential ecological and economic implications for Maryland's agricultural industry and resource conservation efforts managed by the MDA.

The Department of Planning coordinates land use and resource conservation. The availability of incidental taking permits for endangered bats affects statewide land-use policies and the assistance provided to local governments in balancing development with environmental preservation.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates the work of the departments of Planning, Environment, and Natural Resources to balance economic growth with environmental stewardship. This bill directly relates to the initiative's goal of implementing sound land-use policies while protecting forest lands and biodiversity.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Employment and Insurance Equality for Service Members Act standardizes and broadens the definitions of military-related terms like "veteran" and "uniformed services" across Maryland law. By aligning State definitions with federal standards, the bill expands eligibility for various benefits—including professional license renewal fee exemptions, expedited licensing, no-interest small business loans, and insurance protections—to include members of the Commissioned Corps of the Public Health Service and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans and Military Families
qa_results.stakeholders: Active duty service members, veterans (including members of the Public Health Service and NOAA), military families, and veteran-owned small businesses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues increase minimally in fiscal 2026 only due to form filings with the Maryland Insurance Administration. Otherwise, state and local finances are not expected to be materially affected, as the expanded definitions apply to a limited number of additional cases.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary advocate for Maryland's veterans and military families, this agency is directly responsible for the 'Military Family' definition changes and is explicitly named to consult with the Department of Commerce on the Uniformed Services Personnel and Veteran-Owned Small Business No-Interest Loan Program.

The bill significantly impacts the Department of Labor by altering definitions and rules for Unemployment Insurance, the Family and Medical Leave Insurance (FAMLI) program, apprenticeship credits for military service, and professional licensing/renewals for various trades overseen by the department.

The bill amends the Economic Development Article to expand eligibility for the Military Personnel and Veteran-Owned Small Business No-Interest Loan Program, which is administered by the Department of Commerce.

The bill makes substantive changes to the Insurance Article, affecting resident insurance producer licenses, travel insurance definitions, long-term care exclusions, and underwriting protections for service members returning from overseas.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency oversees the Veteran-Owned Small Business Enterprise (VSBE) procurement program, which is affected by the bill's expanded definition of 'veteran' and 'uniformed services' within the State Finance and Procurement Article.

The bill modifies rules regarding automobile insurance eligibility and underwriting standards for uniformed services personnel returning from active duty, which directly impacts MAIF's operations as the insurer of last resort.

The bill amends the Commercial Law Article regarding consumer credit reporting and 'protected consumers' (including eligible service members), which falls under the OAG's Consumer Protection Division oversight.
As the central procurement unit for the state, DGS is impacted by changes to the definitions governing Veteran-Owned Small Business Enterprise (VSBE) participation goals and procurement rules.

The bill affects licensing and registration definitions that may apply to healthcare practitioners who are members of the uniformed services (including the Public Health Service) seeking license renewals or expedited status.
The Governor's Office oversees the administrative and policy implementation of the bill's uniform military definitions across all executive branch agencies.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the existing property tax exemption for dwelling houses owned and occupied by blind individuals or their surviving spouses, raising the exempt portion of the home's assessed value from $15,000 to $40,000.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation
qa_results.stakeholders: Blind individuals and their surviving spouses who own and reside in a dwelling house occupied by not more than two families.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State revenues for the Annuity Bond Fund are projected to decrease by approximately $40,000 annually starting in FY 2026. Local property tax revenues are projected to decrease by approximately $450,000 annually beginning in FY 2026. There is no expected impact on State or local expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is directly responsible for hearing appeals from property owners regarding property tax assessments and the rejection of property tax exemptions, which this bill modifies.

As the state's cross-disability policy leader, this agency advocates for the rights of individuals with disabilities, including blind individuals, and guides policy regarding accessible and affordable housing.

The Maryland Tax Court serves as the highest level of administrative review for tax controversies, including property tax assessment disputes and exemptions, which could arise from the implementation of this bill.

As the state's chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller monitors state revenue impacts and oversees the fiscal health of the state, including the state property tax revenues affected by this bill.

The Treasurer manages the state's banking and bond funds. The fiscal note indicates that this bill reduces revenues for the Annuity Bond Fund, which is used to pay debt service on state bonds managed by this office.
DBM is responsible for estimating state revenues and formulating the budget. It must account for the reduction in state property tax revenue described in the fiscal note.
The Governor's Office oversees all state departments and responsible for signing legislation into law, including the fiscal impact of tax exemptions on the state's annual budget.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies regarding the interpretation and enforcement of tax laws and property exemptions.
The BPW protects the state's fiscal integrity and oversees state property and capital improvements; it is concerned with the health of the Annuity Bond Fund used for state infrastructure debt.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the number of speed monitoring systems that may be placed on Interstate 83 in Baltimore City from two to four, while limiting operation to one camera in each direction at any given time. It also makes the authorization for these systems permanent by repealing a previous sunset date.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore City Government and Baltimore City Department of Transportation
qa_results.stakeholders: Motorists traveling on Interstate 83 in Baltimore City and the Baltimore City government.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues may increase starting in FY 2026 due to additional contested cases in District Court. Baltimore City revenues and expenditures are expected to increase because the bill makes the speed camera program on Interstate 83 permanent; without this bill, the program would have terminated at the end of FY 2026. In fiscal 2024, the two existing cameras on Interstate 83 generated $5.6 million in revenue.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office serves as the principal executive authority that oversees departments such as MDOT and DBM, manages the state budget process affected by revenue changes, and is responsible for signing this legislation into law.

As the state's fiscal watchdog and tax collector, the Comptroller monitors state revenue streams. Speed monitoring system laws require the remittance of excess revenues to the Comptroller, and the agency tracks general fund increases from contested citations.

DBM is the state's central fiscal authority responsible for estimating revenues and managing the budget. The bill's projected increase in general fund revenue from District Court fines necessitates DBM's oversight in budget planning.

MDOT oversees the state's transportation network and policy framework. This bill directly amends the Transportation Article concerning speed monitoring systems on a major interstate, impacting the state's transportation safety strategies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP is the central hub for public safety policy. Automated speed enforcement on interstates is a data-driven public safety and crime prevention strategy that falls under the office's coordination and advisory mandate.

The fiscal note indicates a significant increase in contested speed camera citations adjudicated in the District Court. The AOC provides the administrative, financial, and technological infrastructure required to support this increased judicial caseload.

The MSP is the primary statewide law enforcement agency for highway safety and traffic control. Changes to automated speed enforcement on interstates align with their mission of crash prevention and motor vehicle law enforcement.

The MVA manages vehicle registrations and enforces regulatory compliance. Speed monitoring citations are civil penalties that are typically enforced through registration holds or blocks administered by the MVA for non-payment.

As a unit of MDOT responsible for non-tolled highways, SHA establishes the traffic control device standards and signage requirements that speed monitoring systems on Interstate 83 must legally follow.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows a court to issue a permanent protective order if the individual against whom the order is sought consents to its issuance. Previously, permanent protective orders were primarily issued based on specific criminal convictions and terms of imprisonment; this act expands the criteria to include mutual consent.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary (Administrative Office of the Courts)
qa_results.stakeholders: Victims of abuse and individuals subject to protective orders (respondents)
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures for the Judiciary increase by $30,300 in fiscal 2026 only for one-time programming costs. The bill is not otherwise expected to materially affect State or local finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The AOC is the primary agency impacted as the bill requires changes to judicial programming and court procedures for the issuance of permanent protective orders. The fiscal note explicitly identifies one-time programming costs for the Judiciary.
The Maryland State Police are responsible for enforcing protective orders, including the mandatory surrender of firearms by respondents and the maintenance of safety records throughout the state.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS), which acts as the central repository for protective order information and is utilized by law enforcement to monitor compliance.
DHS oversees child and adult welfare services and works directly with vulnerable individuals who may seek permanent protective orders following domestic abuse.

The Secretary of State manages the 'Safe at Home' Address Confidentiality Program, which provides essential protection for victims of domestic violence and human trafficking who often utilize protective orders.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency coordinates statewide public safety policy and manages funding for victim services, which are directly related to the legal protections afforded by permanent protective orders.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The OPD represents indigent individuals in various legal matters, including criminal cases where the underlying acts of abuse or violations of protective orders may lead to a loss of liberty.
The OAG serves as the chief legal advisor for the State and provides guidance on the enforcement and interpretation of the Family Law Article and consumer/public protection interests.
MDOA provides advocacy and protection for older adults; permanent protective orders are a significant tool in their mission to prevent elder abuse and protect vulnerable seniors.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Public Health Abortion Grant Program and the Public Health Abortion Grant Program Fund within the Maryland Department of Health. The program's purpose is to provide grants to eligible organizations to improve access to abortion care clinical services for individuals who are uninsured, underinsured, or unable to safely use their insurance. The program is primarily funded by transferring excess premium funds from health insurance carriers' segregated accounts established under the federal Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act for abortion coverage.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Uninsured and underinsured individuals seeking abortion care, healthcare practitioners and organizations providing reproductive health services, and health insurance carriers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Maryland Department of Health special fund revenues increase by approximately $19.3 million in FY 2026 and by $2.5 million annually thereafter due to the transfer of excess funds from carrier accounts. Special fund expenditures increase by $2.0 million in FY 2026 and $2.5 million annually thereafter to provide grants and cover administrative costs, including the hiring of two part-time staff members. General fund revenues increase minimally from interest earnings through FY 2028.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Public Health Abortion Grant Program and its associated special fund within the Maryland Department of Health (MDH). The Secretary of Health is responsible for administering the fund, providing operating grants to eligible organizations, and developing standards for the program.

The Insurance Commissioner is tasked with ordering the transfer of 90% of the ending balances from insurance carriers' segregated abortion coverage accounts to the new Grant Program Fund. The MIA must also approve reporting forms and manage potential appeals from carriers regarding these transfers.

The bill mandates the Governor to allocate $2,000,000 to the program by budget amendment by October 1, 2025, and requires the Governor to include specific appropriations in the annual budget bill starting in fiscal year 2027.
The State Treasurer is responsible for holding the Public Health Abortion Grant Program Fund separately and investing its money in the same manner as other state money.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the new special fund and ensuring that interest earnings accrue properly according to state law.

DBM will oversee the budget amendment process mandated by the bill and manage the personnel requirements for MDH, which the fiscal note indicates will require two new part-time positions to manage the grant program.

The bill provides insurance carriers with the right to a hearing and appeal if they are aggrieved by an order from the Insurance Commissioner regarding the transfer of funds; such hearings are typically conducted by the OAH.

As the legal advisor to state agencies, the OAG would be involved in defending the state's implementation of the program, particularly regarding the bill's interaction with the federal Affordable Care Act and potential litigation from insurance carriers.
OLA is responsible for auditing state agencies and special funds; the creation of a new $19.3 million special fund will fall under their periodic fiscal compliance audit scope.
