qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Transportation Trust Fund (TTF) revenues are estimated to increase by a total of approximately $554,600 between FY 2026 and FY 2028 due to a new one-time $8.50 registration fee per vehicle. TTF expenditures are estimated to increase by $812,600 during the same period to cover the production and mailing of the new registration plates. No significant fiscal impact is expected beyond FY 2028.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Transportation and its Motor Vehicle Administration. The office also signed the legislation into law and oversees the state’s annual budget, which is impacted by the changes to the Transportation Trust Fund.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for overseeing the state's budget and estimating revenues. This bill has a notable fiscal impact on the Transportation Trust Fund (TTF), increasing both revenues and expenditures from fiscal 2026 through 2028.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS, through Maryland Correctional Enterprises (MCE), is responsible for the manufacture of all state registration plates. The bill's requirement for a new distinctive 'FLEET VEHICLE' plate for approximately 65,250 vehicles represents a significant production task for the agency.

MDOT is the parent agency of the Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA) and is responsible for the state's transportation network and the Transportation Trust Fund. It will oversee the implementation of the alternative registration process and manage the associated fiscal effects.

Maryland State Police officers enforce motor vehicle laws on state highways. The bill's provision to eliminate validation tabs (stickers) and introduce distinctive plates for rental fleets changes the visual verification process used by officers during traffic stops and registration enforcement.

The Board of Public Works must approve significant state expenditures and procurement contracts. The estimated cost for producing and mailing the new registration plates (exceeding $293,000 in fiscal 2026) may trigger the Board's oversight and approval requirements.

The MVA is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill. It must establish the alternative registration process, issue the distinctive plates, manage the synchronized expiration dates for fleet vehicles, and collect the one-time initial registration fees.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Transportation Authority (MDTA) to establish an installment payment plan program for individuals who have accumulated at least $300 in unpaid video tolls and associated civil penalties. It also expands the Authority's power to recall delinquent accounts from the Central Collection Unit (CCU) and requires the adoption of regulations regarding eligibility, verification, and payment options.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Transportation Authority
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland motor vehicle owners with at least $300 in unpaid video tolls and civil penalties.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State operations or finances because the Maryland Transportation Authority is already in the process of implementing a similar installment payment plan program. There is no local fiscal impact. The expanded authority to recall delinquent accounts from the Central Collection Unit is also not anticipated to have a material fiscal impact as the agency does not plan to change current debt recall practices.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly mandates the Maryland Transportation Authority (MDTA) to establish and administer an installment payment plan program for unpaid video tolls and associated civil penalties, including the adoption of necessary regulations.

As the parent department for both the Motor Vehicle Administration and the Maryland Transportation Authority, MDOT coordinates the transportation debt collection and enforcement policies affected by this legislation.

The MVA is responsible for enforcing toll compliance by refusing or suspending vehicle registrations for individuals who fail to pay tolls or adhere to the installment plans established under the bill.

The bill requires that unpaid toll debts resulting from defaulted installment plans be referred to the Central Collection Unit (CCU), which is a division administered by the Department of Budget and Management.
The OAG acts as legal counsel for MDTA and MDOT and will be involved in the drafting and legal review of the regulations required to implement the installment payment program.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies responsible for implementation and sets policy priorities regarding economic relief and transportation service accessibility.
The bill preserves the option for individuals to elect to stand trial for toll violations; the Judiciary handles the processing of these cases and the associated trial notices.
OAH may be required to provide hearings for individuals challenging registration suspensions or other administrative enforcement actions taken by the MVA following an installment plan default.
OLA is responsible for auditing the financial operations of state agencies and will review the fiscal management and compliance of the new toll installment program during regular audits.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires local jurisdictions in Maryland to adopt laws by October 1, 2026, authorizing the development of accessory dwelling units (ADUs) on land containing a single-family detached dwelling. The bill establishes standards for ADU construction, prevents local jurisdictions from including ADUs in density calculations, limits setback requirements, and restricts homeowners associations from imposing unreasonable limitations on ADU development. It also allows HOAs to treat ADUs as separate lots for the purposes of voting and assessments.
qa_results.responsible_party: Local legislative bodies (counties and municipalities) and their respective zoning agencies
qa_results.stakeholders: Single-family residential property owners, potential ADU renters, local governments, homeowners associations (HOAs), and small businesses in the construction industry.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to directly affect State finances. Local government expenditures and revenues may be affected by the requirement to develop and adopt new local laws, conduct mandatory parking studies if additional parking requirements are established, and process increased ADU development applications. While local jurisdictions may see increased fee revenue, the net direct fiscal impact cannot be reliably estimated.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill modifies state laws regarding real property and homeowner association (HOA) rules, which are subject to judicial interpretation and litigation handled by the Maryland court system. The agency was also listed as an information source in the fiscal note.

The bill addresses public health standards for residential dwellings, including safe drinking water and sewage disposal, which are core areas of oversight for the department and its local health branches.

As the primary agency for expanding affordable housing access and neighborhood revitalization, the department is directly impacted by legislation aimed at increasing the housing supply through accessory dwelling units.

The department is the primary agency for land use policy and historically coordinates housing density and sustainable growth. Additionally, its Maryland Historical Trust is specifically designated to identify historic properties exempt from certain provisions of the bill.
The bill establishes parking requirement exemptions based on proximity to mass transit facilities, which are planned and operated by the department through its various business units like the MTA.

The bill references sanitary commissions and municipal authorities regulated under the Environment Article and addresses essential infrastructure such as water and sewer main connections for new dwelling units.
This legislation represents a major executive branch priority on housing affordability and availability. The Governor’s Office oversees the broader policy goals that this land use reform serves.
The bill affects real property rights and the governing instruments of homeowners associations (HOAs), areas frequently involving consumer protection and legal disputes overseen by the OAG.

The bill defines and regulates utility connections for accessory dwelling units, specifically referencing private water and sewer companies that are under the regulatory jurisdiction of the Commission.

The Secretary of State’s office was identified as an information source and often handles administrative filings and regulations relevant to homeowner association declarations and community governance.
This multi-agency initiative focuses on sustainable growth and smart growth land-use policies; the promotion of ADUs is a key strategy for increasing density and reducing urban sprawl.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the procedures for special taxing districts established for shore erosion control projects. In Anne Arundel County, it removes the requirement that 75% of property owners must sign a petition before an erosion control project can be planned or constructed, and it waives certain notice and hearing requirements. Statewide, the bill mandates that interest earned on a district's funds must be credited back to that district and allows districts to use tax funds for the maintenance and repair of existing projects without a petition, provided a public hearing is held.
qa_results.responsible_party: County governing bodies (acting as district councils) and entities administering shore erosion control districts
qa_results.stakeholders: Real property owners in shore erosion control districts (specifically in Anne Arundel County), county governments, and small businesses involved in erosion prevention construction and planning.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not affect State finances. Local fiscal impacts include a potential acceleration or increase in expenditures and revenues for special taxing districts in Anne Arundel County due to the removal of petition and hearing requirements. Additionally, the bill may increase the use of district tax funds for project maintenance statewide. Interest earnings on district deposits must now be credited specifically to the districts, though this is not expected to materially affect overall county finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly supplements the provisions of the Natural Resources Article relating to shore erosion control projects. The Department is responsible for the preservation and management of Maryland's water and living resources, including the Chesapeake Bay, and was consulted in the bill's fiscal analysis.

The Department is responsible for coordinating land use and sustainable growth efforts. This bill affects local land use, special taxing districts, and community-level erosion control planning, particularly in Anne Arundel County, and the agency was identified as an information source for the legislation.

The Department is the state's primary regulatory agency for protecting water and land resources. This bill addresses shoreline erosion control, which frequently involves environmental permitting and standards regulated by this agency.

As a self-supporting state agency that manages environmental projects for local and state government, MES could be involved in the technical operation or implementation of shoreline restoration and erosion control projects funded by these special taxing districts.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates the work of the Departments of Planning, Environment, and Natural Resources to promote sustainable growth and improve the health of the Chesapeake Bay, both of which are central to shoreline erosion control policy.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation. Governor Wes Moore signed this bill into law as an emergency measure.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Prince George’s County Department of Permitting, Inspections, and Enforcement to record a lien on a property within 90 days of issuing a notice of violation for unauthorized tree cutting or clearing in the Critical Area. Recording the lien is necessary to hold a subsequent good-faith purchaser liable for the violation. The bill applies retroactively to violations occurring on or before November 7, 2018, requiring the county to vacate enforcement actions and reimburse property owners for associated costs and fees.
qa_results.responsible_party: Prince George’s County Department of Permitting, Inspections, and Enforcement (DPIE)
qa_results.stakeholders: Current and previous owners of non-commercial real property parcels of less than five acres in the Prince George's County Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no direct effect on State finances. Prince George’s County expenditures are expected to increase by approximately $40,000 in FY 2026 to reimburse costs and fees for a property owner affected by the bill's retroactive provisions. Local revenues are not affected.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically requires the Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays (which falls under this category of executive commissions) to adopt regulations authorizing a person to appeal certain enforcement actions related to tree cutting or clearing.

The Critical Area Commission is an independent unit within the Department of Natural Resources (DNR). Additionally, the bill involves the State Forester, a DNR official, in the preparation of replanting plans for violations.
The bill outlines legal enforcement procedures where the Chair of the Critical Area Commission may refer violations to the Attorney General to bring civil actions for damages or injunctive relief.
The bill establishes legal frameworks for appeals and requires circuit courts to assess damages for tree-clearing violations, impacting judicial proceedings and administrative support for the courts.

The Department of Planning is responsible for coordinating land use and sustainable growth policy; the Critical Area Program is a significant land use regulation that intersects with the department's mission.
As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees the operations of the Department of Natural Resources and the Critical Area Commission, and the Governor signed the bill into law.
The Critical Area Program is a key component of Maryland's smart growth and environmental stewardship efforts, which are core objectives of this multi-agency initiative.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands existing state requirements to ensure equal access to public services for individuals with limited English proficiency (LEP) and specifically includes individuals with disabilities. It requires state departments and agencies to develop and update biennial language access plans, provide language assistance services (including sign language, Braille, and large print), and translate vital documents into any language spoken by at least 0.5% of the state population. The bill also establishes the Maryland Language Advisory Group, co-chaired and staffed by the Governor’s Office of Immigrant Affairs and the Maryland Department of Disabilities, to oversee compliance and provide implementation templates.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Governor’s Office of Immigrant Affairs and the Maryland Department of Disabilities
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents with limited English proficiency, individuals with disabilities, and Maryland State departments and agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by approximately $56,000 in FY 2026 for the Governor’s Office of Immigrant Affairs to hire staff for the Maryland Language Advisory Group. Total state expenditures across multiple agencies are projected to increase significantly, likely exceeding $1,500,000 annually starting in FY 2027, as departments implement language access plans and translation services. The Department of Human Services may see an increase in matching federal fund revenues. Local government finances are not materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office of Immigrant Affairs (GOIA) is the primary agency responsible for overseeing, monitoring, and enforcing the bill's provisions, and it co-chairs and staffs the Maryland Language Advisory Group.
The department is a primary lead on the bill, co-chairing the Maryland Language Advisory Group and sharing staffing responsibilities for oversight and enforcement.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The director is a mandated member of the Maryland Language Advisory Group and the office provides technical assistance on language access for the deaf and hard of hearing.
The State Superintendent is a mandated member of the Maryland Language Advisory Group, and the department is specifically required to fully implement language access plans by 2028.
The Secretary is a member of the Advisory Group, and the department is tasked with helping identify independent agencies for compliance and must fully implement its own language access plan.
The Secretary is a member of the Advisory Group, and the department is specifically required to fully implement language access plans by 2028, with significant fiscal impact noted.
The Secretary is a member of the Advisory Group, and the department is specifically required to fully implement language access plans by 2028.
The Secretary is a member of the Advisory Group, and the agency provides technical support for digital language access and translation services mentioned in the fiscal note.
The OAG is specifically required to fully implement language access plans and collaborates with DHS to determine which independent agencies must comply with the bill.
The Comptroller is specifically listed as an agency required to achieve full implementation of language access plans by July 1, 2028.
The State Police are specifically listed as an agency required to achieve full implementation of language access plans, with notable fiscal impacts for staffing and translation.
As a principal department, MDOT must implement language access plans, and several of its units are specifically identified in the bill and fiscal note.
The MTA is explicitly named in the bill as an agency required to achieve full implementation of language access plans by 2028.
The MVA is highlighted in the fiscal note as requiring upgrades to its language access plan and customer service for individuals with limited English proficiency.
The Commission is specifically named as an agency that must fully implement language access plans by July 1, 2028.
The Commission is specifically named as an agency that must fully implement language access plans by July 1, 2028.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates the Maryland Language Advisory Group (MLAG) as a multi-agency body to oversee compliance, monitoring, and reporting.
As a principal department, Aging is required to implement language access plans; the fiscal note projects costs for contractual services and document translation.
The department is a principal department mandated to fully implement a language access plan and provide equal access services by 2028.
The department is a principal department mandated to implement the bill; the fiscal note identifies specific costs for translation services and supplies.
The department is a principal department mandated to implement the bill; the fiscal note identifies potential administrative staffing needs for compliance.
The department is a principal department mandated to develop and implement a language access plan by 2028.
The department is a principal department mandated to develop and implement a language access plan by 2028.
The department is a principal department mandated to develop and implement a language access plan by 2028.
As a principal department, DNR must implement the plan; the fiscal note suggests additional staff may be needed to oversee compliance.
The department is a principal department mandated to implement the bill; the fiscal note anticipates staffing needs for in-person interpretation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The department is a principal department mandated to develop and implement a language access plan by 2028.
The department is a principal department mandated to develop and implement a language access plan by 2028.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Service and Civic Innovation
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The department is a principal department mandated to develop and implement a language access plan by 2028.
As a principal department, MDEM must implement language access plans, which specifically include 'vital documents' related to emergency preparedness.
As a principal department, DBM must implement the bill; it also manages the statewide personnel and fiscal authority relevant to the bill's appropriations and staffing needs.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a temporary telehealth license issued by the State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists. It allows out-of-state licensed professional counselors to provide clinical professional counseling services via telehealth to students who are out-of-state residents enrolled in and residing at or near an institution of higher education in Maryland, provided a therapeutic relationship of at least six months has already been established. The temporary license is valid for six months and cannot be renewed.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists
qa_results.stakeholders: Out-of-state residents enrolled in Maryland institutions of higher education and out-of-state licensed professional counselors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have a minimal fiscal impact. Any additional workload on the State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists can be absorbed within existing budgeted resources. Revenue from temporary license application fees is assumed to be minimal. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates the State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists, which is a regulatory body within the Department of Health, to establish and manage a temporary telehealth license, including the adoption of regulations for qualifications and fees.

The bill specifically creates a licensing category to provide mental health services to students enrolled in institutions of higher education in Maryland, which aligns with the Commission's role in coordinating policy for these institutions and ensuring student welfare.

As the governing body for 12 public universities in Maryland, USM has a direct interest in policies that expand mental health access for its students via telehealth, particularly for those with pre-existing therapeutic relationships with out-of-state providers.

As an independent state university, Morgan State's students are direct beneficiaries of the bill's provisions allowing continued telehealth counseling from out-of-state providers while they are enrolled and residing in Maryland.

The college's students are part of the specific population (out-of-state residents enrolled in a Maryland institution of higher education) for whom the temporary telehealth license is designed to facilitate continued mental health care.

The OAG acts as the legal advisor to the State Board of Professional Counselors and Therapists and would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the development of regulations and enforcement procedures for the new temporary license.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies involved (MDH and the Board) and coordinates statewide initiatives related to public safety, healthcare access, and student well-being.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland State Department of Education to establish a workgroup to analyze the mixed delivery, publicly funded prekindergarten system. The workgroup will evaluate policy differences between public and private providers, reimbursement and invoicing processes, administrative requirements, and methods for including students with disabilities in integrated classrooms. It must provide an interim report by June 1, 2026, and a final report by December 31, 2027.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Public and private prekindergarten providers, child care centers, family child care providers, Head Start programs, prekindergarten students and their families, and students with disabilities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland State Department of Education can staff the required workgroup using existing resources, though some resources may be diverted from other projects. There is no impact on local government finances or small businesses. Revenues are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, MSDE is mandated to convene and staff the workgroup, designate various members, and conduct a comprehensive analysis of the publicly funded prekindergarten system, including the Maryland EXCELS program and various grant initiatives.
The bill explicitly requires the State Superintendent of Schools to designate a representative from the Maryland Department of Health to serve on the workgroup.

The workgroup is specifically tasked with analyzing how to best use prekindergarten programs to provide quality education for students with disabilities in inclusive classrooms, including the delivery of specialized services.

The analysis must review the challenges for prekindergarten providers in building or adapting facilities to accommodate students, which directly relates to the IAC's mission of overseeing and funding school infrastructure.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a specialized workgroup consisting of state officials, legislators, and private stakeholders to conduct policy research and provide recommendations to the General Assembly.
The bill requires a representative from the Office of the State Fire Marshal, which is a unit of the Maryland State Police, to serve as a member of the workgroup.
The workgroup is tasked with developing methods to foster collaboration between providers in delivering specialized transportation for students with disabilities.
The bill requires a representative from a community college with an early childhood education program to join the workgroup; MHEC is the regulatory body overseeing these institutions.

The analysis of prekindergarten systems and educational equity for families directly aligns with the GOC's mission to address childhood poverty and improve family well-being through whole-of-government coordination.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires an analysis of private prekindergarten providers, many of whom are small businesses, regarding reimbursement methods, administrative burdens, and opportunities to pool resources like employee benefits.
The bill relates to the implementation of the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, a key executive priority, and requires reports to be submitted to the Accountability and Implementation Board.

The workgroup is required to analyze reimbursement methods for private providers, including the feasibility of forward funding, which impacts the state's fiscal and tax-collection operations managed by the Comptroller.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health (MDH), in consultation with various stakeholders, to submit a report to the General Assembly by December 31, 2025, regarding the feasibility of establishing and maintaining an online directory of home health care providers. The proposed directory would allow individuals to search for providers based on criteria like language proficiency and certifications, while also supporting workforce recruitment, training opportunities, and emergency communication.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals seeking home health care services, home health care providers, residential service agencies, the Maryland Department of Aging, and health care worker organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Department of Aging can consult with stakeholders and submit the required report using existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state or local revenues or local expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDH is the lead agency mandated to consult with stakeholders and submit the feasibility report. The report must review existing programs within MDH's Office of Health Care Quality and investigate the integration of home health providers into the Medicaid program.
The bill explicitly requires MDH to consult with the Maryland Department of Aging during the preparation of the feasibility report on the home health care provider directory.
The feasibility report must include a review of existing home health care consumer resources and service programs already available through the Maryland Health Care Commission.

The feasibility report must explore using the proposed directory to connect providers with training and workforce development opportunities, which aligns with the Department of Labor's core mission and programs.
Home health care services are critical for the independence of individuals with disabilities. MDOD coordinates policy and improvements for such services to ensure community-based living.
The report must consider the directory's utility in facilitating communication with health care providers during public health or other emergencies, which is a key function of MDEM.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Adapted Vehicle Access Pilot Program within the Maryland Department of Disabilities to provide adapted motor vehicles to eligible licensed drivers who require mobility aids. The program prioritizes individuals residing in areas with limited public transportation and is funded through solicited donations of vehicles, services, and funds, as well as federal grants. The department is required to study the program's impact on recipients' independence and mobility and report its findings by December 1, 2028.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Disabilities
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed drivers who require a mobility aid (such as a wheelchair) and live in areas with limited public transportation.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of Disabilities expects to absorb the pilot program's administrative costs using existing budgeted resources. Federal and special fund revenues and expenditures may increase by an indeterminate amount from fiscal 2026 through 2030 depending on the receipt of federal grants and private donations. Local government finances are not materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Disabilities is the primary agency responsible for implementing and administering the Adapted Vehicle Access Pilot Program, including selecting participants and reporting on program outcomes.

The bill defines eligible individuals as licensed drivers qualified to drive adapted vehicles; the MVA oversees driver licensing and would likely be involved in certifying driver qualifications for these modified vehicles.

The program is required to prioritize individuals residing in areas with limited access to public transportation, a challenge that disproportionately affects rural Marylanders and aligns with the Council's advocacy mission.

The bill mandates that the Department of Disabilities apply for and facilitate federal funds and grants to implement the program, which falls under the GGO's core responsibility of assisting agencies with federal funding.
MDOT oversees both the MVA and transit accessibility; the program's focus on individuals with limited public transit access directly intersects with the department's transportation planning.
The Department of Disabilities is required to submit a comprehensive report on the pilot program's results and recommendations for extension or expansion to the Governor by December 2028.
DBM provides fiscal oversight for the state and would be involved in managing the special and federal fund increases resulting from donations and grants for the program.
The pilot program is required to study the impact on recipients' job opportunities, which is a key focus area for the Department of Labor's workforce development efforts.
The board advises on pathways to employment; the program's goal to improve job opportunities for individuals with disabilities through better mobility aligns with the board's strategic mission.
Many veterans with service-connected disabilities require adapted vehicles; DVMF acts as an advocate and resource hub for this population and could coordinate with the program.
The Maryland ABLE program, managed by this agency, allows individuals with disabilities to save for transportation expenses like adapted vehicles, suggesting potential for program coordination.
The OAG would provide legal counsel to the Department of Disabilities regarding the legalities of accepting vehicle donations and liability issues surrounding the pilot program.
The program prioritizes those with limited transit access; the MTA manages regional transit systems and paratransit services for the same target demographic.

This unit focuses on data-driven solutions for economic mobility and modernizing government services, which mirrors the pilot program's goal of improving independence for low-income or underserved disabled residents.
The bill requires tracking specific performance metrics such as mobility and independence impacts, which aligns with GOPI's mission of data-driven decision making and strategic planning.
The program tracks long-term outcomes like job opportunities and dependency on public subsidies, which may involve data linkages supported by the MLDS Center.
Through the Division of Rehabilitation Services (DORS), MSDE helps individuals with disabilities achieve employment, making them a likely partner or referral source for this pilot program.
OLA will likely perform fiscal compliance and performance audits on the new pilot program to ensure proper handling of donations and federal funds.
The program promotes equal opportunity and accessibility in transportation for disabled residents, which is part of the Commission's broader mandate to ensure anti-discrimination and inclusion.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a Class MT (movie theater) beer, wine, and liquor license in Howard County, allowing movie theater owners who hold crowd control training certification to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption to ticketed patrons. The Howard County Board of License Commissioners is authorized to set license fees, hours of sale, and other regulations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Howard County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Movie theater owners and operators in Howard County, and movie theater patrons.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state fiscal impact. Howard County license revenues will increase based on the number of Class MT licenses issued and the fee amount yet to be determined by the Board of License Commissioners. Any additional enforcement or administrative activity can be handled by the county using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation, including this local bill for Howard County. Furthermore, the Governor is responsible for appointing the members of the Howard County Board of License Commissioners, the body authorized by this bill to issue Class MT licenses and set relevant fees and regulations.

The bill grants authority to the Howard County Board of License Commissioners to regulate the new license category. The Office of Appointments is responsible for vetting and recruiting candidates for Maryland's boards and commissions, which includes the local liquor boards tasked with implementing this law.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to state agencies and boards. It may be required to provide legal guidance to the Howard County Board of License Commissioners regarding the drafting of regulations for the Class MT license and ensure that local policies align with the Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland.

As the state's chief tax collector and fiscal watchdog, the Comptroller oversees the collection of excise and sales taxes related to alcoholic beverages. While the license itself is local, the expansion of alcohol sales to movie theaters impacts the revenue streams managed by this office.

The Department of Commerce is responsible for stimulating private investment and economic growth. This bill creates a new business opportunity for movie theaters in Howard County, potentially increasing their economic viability and expanding the retail sector, which aligns with the department's mission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill renames the Baltimore City AIDS Prevention Sterile Needle and Syringe Exchange Pilot Program to the HIV Prevention Syringe Services Program. It updates syringe distribution requirements, revises the membership and responsibilities of the program oversight committee, modifies data collection and evaluation procedures, and clarifies criminal immunity for program staff and participants.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore City Health Department
qa_results.stakeholders: Injecting drug users in Baltimore City, Baltimore City Health Department staff, addiction treatment providers, and the Maryland Department of Health.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state or local fiscal impact as the bill primarily updates program terminology and oversight structures without requiring additional expenditures or generating new revenue.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) by requiring its Center for Harm Reduction to operate the Rapid Analysis of Drugs Program, which will receive and analyze returned syringes from the Baltimore City program. Additionally, MDH retains a designated seat on the program's oversight committee.
The bill requires the Baltimore City Health Department to submit an annual report to the Governor detailing the number of hypodermic needles and syringes exchanged under the program.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill removes the requirement for the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services to nominate a law enforcement representative to the program's oversight committee.
The bill removes the Department of Education as a potential source of representatives for the program's oversight committee, streamlining membership to only MDH for that specific category.
The bill removes the Department of Juvenile Services as a potential source of representatives for the program's oversight committee.

The bill alters the criminal immunity provisions for program staff and participants regarding the possession and distribution of drug paraphernalia, which impacts statewide law enforcement activities and the enforcement of state criminal law.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's central hub for public safety policy and substance abuse coordination, GOCPP is impacted by changes to criminal law immunity and statewide harm reduction strategies addressed in this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill creates a Paid Family and Medical Leave program for all Maryland Executive Branch employees, including temporary staff and those at public universities. Starting July 1, 2026, it replaces the current parental leave program and provides up to 12 weeks of leave at full pay for the birth or adoption of a child, serious health conditions of the employee or a family member, or military-related needs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Secretary of Budget and Management and the governing bodies of public institutions of higher education
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland Executive Branch employees, including temporary staff and employees of public institutions of higher education
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures are expected to decrease significantly in FY 2026 (potentially by over $35,000,000 annually) because the State will not make employer contributions to the FAMLI program. Beginning in FY 2027, expenditures will increase to provide fully paid leave benefits and for program administration. Special fund revenues for the FAMLI Fund will decrease because it will not receive contributions from the State or its employees. The net fiscal impact starting in FY 2027 is indeterminate.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Secretary of Budget and Management is the primary official responsible for adopting regulations, establishing procedures, and administering the new paid family and medical leave program for the Executive Branch.
As a governing body of public institutions of higher education, USM is explicitly required to adopt regulations governing paid family and medical leave for its employees under the bill.
Morgan State University is a public institution of higher education whose governing body is specifically tasked by the bill with adopting and administering the new leave benefit regulations.
As a public institution of higher education, the college's governing body is required by the bill to implement regulations for the new family and medical leave program.
The bill requires DBM to file quarterly wage and hour reports with the Department of Labor and utilizes Labor's FAMLI program infrastructure for the appeals process for leave denials.

The Comptroller manages the state's central payroll for over 100,000 employees and will be responsible for integrating the new paid leave category into the payroll system and managing the associated fiscal impacts.
The bill establishes personnel policy across the entire Executive Branch, which is overseen by the Governor's Office, and repeals existing parental leave laws signed by the executive.

The bill includes specific 'qualifying exigency' leave related to the deployment and military events of service members, including the National Guard, which falls under the Adjutant General's command.

The legislation provides specialized leave benefits for family members of service members and those caring for service members with serious health conditions, aligning with the agency's advocacy for military families.
OLA is responsible for auditing the fiscal compliance and financial controls of executive agencies, which will include the administration of this significant new personnel expenditure.
The OAG will provide legal counsel to DBM and higher education boards to ensure that the new regulations comply with state and federal personnel laws.
MCCR oversees anti-discrimination in employment; the implementation of a new state-mandated leave benefit impacts employee rights and potential administrative complaints regarding leave entitlement.

MDOT is a major Executive Branch employer with independent personnel authority in some units; the fiscal note identifies it as a key agency affected by the transition from FAMLI to the state-administered PFML.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill changes how health care providers notify patients before destroying medical records. Providers may now use either first-class mail or email for notification, rather than both. If a provider sends an email and does not receive a response or delivery receipt, they must then send a notice by first-class mail at least 10 days before the record's destruction date.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Patients, parents or guardians of minor patients, and health care providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state or local fiscal impact as the bill's changes are technical. The impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health is the primary regulator for the Health-General Article and the licensing authority for health care providers, who are directly affected by the modified medical record destruction notification requirements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Health Care Alternative Dispute Resolution Office
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Medical records are the primary evidence in medical malpractice arbitration managed by this office; changes to record destruction notification methods affect the preservation and availability of documentation for future claims.
The commission regulates health information technology standards and sets quality performance standards for facilities, which include the protocols for managing and destroying medical records.

The commission adjudicates claims for workplace injuries where the availability of long-term medical records is essential; notification standards for destruction impact the evidentiary record for ongoing or subsequent claims.

The MCA regulates medical cannabis licensees and maintains patient and caregiver records, making the notification requirements for the destruction of medical documentation relevant to their compliance oversight.

This office monitors the legal medical use of controlled substances through patient records and regular inspections of registrants, ensuring that record-keeping and destruction protocols protect public health.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MIEMSS coordinates the statewide EMS system and regulates clinicians who generate medical records; the agency must ensure that record retention and destruction protocols align with state health standards.
The OAG acts as the chief legal advisor for state health agencies and boards and is responsible for interpreting and enforcing statutes related to patient privacy and medical record management.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages health care services and medical records for incarcerated individuals within state facilities, making the administrative requirements for record destruction notification relevant to their operations.
The department operates the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home, a skilled nursing facility that must comply with state laws regarding the maintenance and destruction of patient medical records.
The Exchange manages significant amounts of health and insurance enrollment data; although it is not a direct healthcare provider, it operates within the state's health data regulatory framework.
As the regulator for hospital quality and cost, the commission is interested in hospital administrative protocols, including those governing the retention and legal disposal of medical records.

As a major writer of workers' compensation insurance that manages claims for state employees, the fund processes and relies on extensive medical records that must be managed according to state destruction laws.
MSDE oversees public schools and child care providers that maintain health records for students, making the legal standards for record destruction notification relevant to educational administration.
Member universities operate student health centers and academic medical programs that maintain and must eventually destroy patient medical records in compliance with state law.
DJS provides medical care to youth in the juvenile justice system and manages their medical records, necessitating compliance with notification protocols when records reach their destruction date.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill exempts passive trusts and trusts established by federal corporate instrumentalities for the purpose of acquiring mortgage loans from Maryland's mortgage lender licensing requirements. It also creates the Maryland Licensing Workgroup to study and make recommendations concerning the state's financial services licensing and registration systems.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of Financial Regulation, Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Passive trusts acquiring mortgage loans, federal corporate instrumentalities, mortgage lenders, financial service providers, and Maryland residents seeking credit.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill affects State special fund revenues and expenditures for the Office of Financial Regulation (OFR). By exempting passive trusts from licensing requirements that would have been required under a recent court ruling, the bill results in foregone licensing revenues and related regulatory expenditures. The OFR can staff the Maryland Licensing Workgroup and cover member reimbursements using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Office of Financial Regulation (OFR), a unit within the Department of Labor, which is responsible for licensing and supervising the state's financial services industry. The Commissioner of Financial Regulation chairs the new Maryland Licensing Workgroup, and the OFR is tasked with providing staff and resources for the workgroup's study on licensing requirements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates the Maryland Licensing Workgroup, a specialized study group within this functional category, tasked with researching and making formal recommendations on financial service licensing laws to the Governor and General Assembly.

The Governor is responsible for appointing members to the Maryland Licensing Workgroup and will receive its final report and recommendations. Additionally, the office oversees the executive agencies (like the Department of Labor) implementing these changes.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor to the Department of Labor and its Office of Financial Regulation. It would provide legal counsel regarding the interpretation of the court decision mentioned in the fiscal note and the implementation of the new passive trust exemptions.

DBM oversees the state's personnel and budget; the fiscal note indicates that workgroup expenses will be absorbed within existing resources, and DBM would monitor the fiscal impact of modified licensing revenues for the Office of Financial Regulation.

This office is responsible for vetting candidates for state boards and commissions and would likely assist the Governor in appointing the members representing the public and financial services experts to the newly created workgroup.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies various prior authorizations of State debt from previous legislative sessions. It updates the names of grant recipients, alters the approved uses for grant funds, extends termination dates for projects, and removes certain matching fund requirements for a wide variety of local and miscellaneous capital projects throughout Maryland.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Board of Public Works
qa_results.stakeholders: Local governments, non-profit organizations, healthcare facilities, educational institutions, and Maryland residents in jurisdictions where capital projects are being developed or renovated.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill modifies the conditions and deadlines under which previously authorized State grant funds may be used, including reallocating funds between projects. According to the fiscal note, these changes do not materially affect State finances as they involve existing debt authorizations. There is no impact on local finances unless the local government is the specific grantee for a modified project.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the principal executive agency, the Governor's Office oversees all state departments and signs legislation regarding state debt authorizations and budget allocations.
The Comptroller is a member of the Board of Public Works, which must certify matching funds and approve the modification of state debt grants and expenditures.
The Treasurer's Office manages the state's debt and bond sales and sits on the Board of Public Works, which oversees the capital projects modified by this bill.
The bill modifies a grant specifically for the East Columbia 50+ Center, a facility serving the older adult population managed within the department's area of advocacy.
The bill alters grants previously intended for a Regional Agricultural Center, impacting the funding landscape for agricultural infrastructure.
DBM is the central fiscal authority responsible for formulating the capital budget and overseeing the state debt authorizations modified by this bill.
The bill modifies grants for projects such as the Kennedy Krieger Institute's LEAP facility, which serves students with autism and pervasive behavioral challenges.
The bill alters several grants related to public high school athletic facilities and charter school infrastructure which fall under the department's oversight.
DGS manages the design, construction, and procurement logistics for various state-funded capital projects and is cited as a source of information regarding these modifications.
The bill significantly modifies grants for numerous healthcare facilities, including hospitals like Sinai, Johns Hopkins, and Adventist Healthcare, as well as crisis stabilization centers.

DHCD is responsible for neighborhood revitalization and community development grants, several of which (such as the Neighborhood Impact Investment Fund and Habitat for Humanity) are modified by the bill.
The bill modifies capital grants managed by DNR's Capital Grants and Loans Administration, specifically changing the scope of projects like the Salisbury Rail Trail/North Prong project.
The bill modifies authorizations for several transportation-related projects, including transit station rebranding, metro station entrances, and municipal parking infrastructure.
The bill includes a specific grant modification for the renovation of the historic 'White House' at the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home.
The Board of Public Works is the primary authority for approving state bond expenditures and certifying matching funds, both of which are central to the alterations made by this bill.
The bill modifies prior authorizations for public school construction and renovation projects, which are overseen and funded through the IAC.
MHEC coordinates statewide policy for higher education institutions; the bill modifies capital grants for private and public colleges such as McDaniel College.
The bill modifies multiple major authorizations for the University of Maryland, College Park, specifically for the Health and Human Sciences facility.
The bill modifies infrastructure grants for water main replacements and environmental restoration projects like the North Prong project in Salisbury.
The bill modifies authorizations for stadium improvements (Arthur Perdue Stadium) and school construction projects, both of which are central to the Authority's mission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill changes the structure of the Wicomico County Board of Education by requiring all seven members to be elected from specific districts rather than having at-large members, beginning with the 2026 election. It adds at least one nonvoting student member to the board, allows for student scholarships and expense reimbursements, and authorizes the Wicomico County Council to increase the salary of board members above the current minimums of $4,000 for the chair and $3,700 for other members.
qa_results.responsible_party: Wicomico County Board of Education, Wicomico County Council, and Wicomico County Board of Elections
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and registered voters of Wicomico County, students of Wicomico County Public Schools, and members of the Wicomico County Board of Education
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state fiscal impact. Local expenditures for the Wicomico County Board of Education will increase if the Wicomico County Council chooses to set salaries higher than current levels or if the board awards scholarships to student members. Expense reimbursements for student and elected members are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing resources. The Wicomico County Board of Elections can implement the change in election districts using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates a significant change in the electoral structure of the Wicomico County Board of Education by replacing the previous five-district and two at-large seat system with seven distinct councilmanic districts for all elected members starting in 2026. As the state authority responsible for maintaining the statewide voter registration database and ensuring uniform compliance with election laws, this agency is responsible for overseeing the implementation of these local district adjustments.

As the primary regulatory body for the state's K-12 public education system, MSDE oversees the governance and operational standards of local boards of education. This bill's changes to board membership (adding student members), compensation structures, and election procedures fall within the department's policy and oversight interests regarding school system leadership.

The Governor's Office is responsible for the final review and signing of legislation. Additionally, the office oversees the executive agencies (SBE and MSDE) that will support the implementation of these changes to the Wicomico County Board of Education.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the State Board of Elections and the Department of Education, ensuring that the redistricting and governance changes for the local school board comply with state constitutional and statutory requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows certain sports wagering facility licensees (specifically Class B-1 and B-2) to request a relocation of their facility. To qualify, the licensee must have been issued their original license on or before September 30, 2023. The relocation must be within the same county, comply with existing location regulations, and receive approval from the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission and the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Class B-1 and B-2 sports wagering facility licensees and the residents and businesses in Maryland counties where these facilities are located.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not have a material impact on State revenues or local government finances. The State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency and the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission can implement the bill's requirements and process relocation requests using existing resources. Small business impacts are expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly identifies the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission, which is the regulatory body within this agency, as the entity responsible for receiving and granting written requests from sports wagering facility licensees to relocate their facilities.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires that any relocation of a sports wagering facility must be approved by the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission (SWARC), which is a specialized executive commission created by the General Assembly to oversee the licensing process.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires applicants for barber and cosmetologist licenses to complete one hour of domestic violence awareness training as a qualification for licensure. The Maryland Department of Labor is tasked with approving training programs that cover recognizing signs of domestic violence, navigating conversations with victims, and connecting them with support resources. Current licensees are also required to complete this training once during their next license renewal period following the bill's effective date.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Barbers, cosmetologists, barber-stylists, estheticians, nail technicians, and applicants for these professional licenses in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures increase by approximately $10,000 in fiscal 2026 for information technology reprogramming to track training completion. Revenues are not materially affected, and there is no fiscal impact on local governments. Small business impacts are expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Labor is the primary implementing agency. It oversees the State Board of Barbers and the State Board of Cosmetologists and is specifically tasked by the bill to approve the domestic violence awareness training programs required for licensure and renewal.
The bill identifies the State Department of Education as an entity that approves barber and cosmetology schools, which are the primary sites for the training required under this legislation.

The Maryland Higher Education Commission is cited in the bill as an authority that approves barber and cosmetology schools, where the mandated domestic violence awareness curriculum would likely be integrated for new students.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency serves as the state's central hub for public safety policy and victim services. The bill's focus on domestic violence awareness and connecting victims with resources aligns with the office's mission to coordinate statewide initiatives to reduce violence and support victims.

The Secretary of State manages the 'Safe at Home' Address Confidentiality Program for victims of domestic violence. Since the bill requires training on connecting clients with support resources, there is programmatic overlap with the Secretary of State's victim advocacy role.

DHS oversees adult welfare and protective services. As the bill requires licensees to be trained in recognizing signs of domestic violence and communicating with victims, these licensees effectively become a referral link to the social services managed by DHS.

The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor to the Department of Labor and its regulatory boards. They will likely be involved in reviewing the new regulations and training approval standards to ensure legal compliance.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the academic program approval process for graduate-level programs in Maryland. It requires private nonprofit institutions of higher education to submit semi-annual letters of intent to the Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC) regarding new graduate programs, aligning their process with that of public four-year institutions. The bill repeals a previous provision that gave five specific public universities a 90-day exclusive window to propose 'emerging workforce need programs.' Additionally, it clarifies that these letters of intent are intended for institutional collaboration and MHEC feedback rather than granting a 'right of first refusal' for specific programs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Public senior higher education institutions, private nonprofit institutions of higher education, and the Maryland Higher Education Commission.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Higher Education Commission can implement the bill's requirements using existing resources. There is no expected material fiscal impact on the revenues or expenditures of public four-year institutions because the exclusive proposal rights being repealed had not yet been implemented. No local fiscal impact is expected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MHEC is the primary regulatory agency responsible for implementing the bill's changes to the academic program approval process, managing the letter of intent system, and updating the State Plan for Higher Education.

As the state's coordinating and regulatory board for postsecondary education, this agency is tasked with identifying workforce needs and overseeing the growth of Maryland's colleges and universities as affected by the bill.
The bill specifically names Morgan State University as one of the institutions whose exclusive 90-day authority to propose emerging workforce need programs is being repealed.

USM oversees four of the five institutions (Bowie State, Coppin State, UMCP, and UMES) that lose their exclusive program proposal authority under the bill, and its member institutions must follow the revised letter of intent process.
As a public senior higher education institution, Saint Mary's College is subject to the new requirements for submitting semi-annual letters of intent regarding intended new graduate-level programs.
The OAG acts as the primary legal advisor for MHEC and state universities, providing counsel on the interpretation and implementation of revised program approval statutes.

The bill requires the State Plan for Higher Education to identify emerging workforce needs, which aligns with the board's mission to create pathways to employment and align education with industry needs.
The Department of Labor is a key stakeholder in identifying regional workforce needs, which are now a required component of the academic program planning process outlined in the bill.
The Department of Commerce is consulted to identify industry partners and workforce gaps that inform MHEC's State Plan for Higher Education and the development of new academic programs.
The MLDS Center tracks student and workforce data, making the efficiency and outcome of new graduate programs approved under these revised processes relevant to their research and reporting mandates.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill implements recommendations from the Program Approval Process Workgroup, a specialized study group formed to resolve disputes regarding academic program duplication and approval.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes an expedited process for 'tenant holding over' eviction actions when the landlord or the landlord’s spouse is an active duty member of the U.S. military who has relocated to Maryland for duty and intends to occupy the property. In such cases, the District Court must schedule a hearing within 45 days of the landlord's complaint. Additionally, if a sheriff or constable fails to serve the summons within 10 days, a private process server is authorized to handle the service.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary (District Court of Maryland)
qa_results.stakeholders: U.S. military service members and their spouses who are landlords, tenants of military-owned properties, the Maryland District Court, and county sheriffs or constables.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect Maryland State or local government operations or finances. Small business impacts, such as those for private process servers, are expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes mandatory expedited hearing timelines (not later than 45 days after a complaint) and new service of process rules for the District Court, which the AOC manages administratively and technologically.
The bill specifically provides legal protections and expedited residential repossession procedures for active-duty service members and their spouses who are relocating to Maryland.
As the Governor's principal advisor on military matters, the Adjutant General oversees the welfare and state-level support for military personnel affected by this legislation.
The Governor oversees all state departments and signs legislation; this bill reflects executive policy regarding the support and relocation of military families in Maryland.
Members of the Maryland National Guard on active-duty status who are relocating within the state may be direct beneficiaries of these expedited hearing provisions.
As the state agency for housing policy, the modifications to the Real Property Article and landlord-tenant holding-over actions fall within its broader policy domain.
The OAG serves as the legal advisor for the state and may be involved in interpreting the documentation and service of process requirements for military landlords.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the legal procedures for wrongful detainer actions by requiring that a court hearing be held within 10 business days after a complaint is filed. It also updates service of process requirements, requiring service within 4 business days, and shortens the timeframe for appealing a judgment from 10 days to 4 days.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary (District Court of Maryland)
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential property owners, occupants of real property without legal right of possession, and the Maryland court system.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State or local government finances or operations. Small business impact is described as minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly alters judicial procedures for wrongful detainer actions in the District Court, specifically mandating that hearings be held within 10 business days of filing, changing service of process requirements, and establishing timelines for appeals and judgments.

As the state agency responsible for housing policy and community stability, DHCD is impacted by legislation that changes the legal requirements for property owners to regain possession of residential real property.

The OAG serves as the primary legal advisor for the state and would be responsible for providing guidance on the implementation of these changes to the Real Property Article and representing the state's interests in related legal matters.

The Governor’s Office oversees the execution of state laws and the operations of all departments. It is also responsible for signing the legislation and coordinating policy related to public safety and economic opportunity which includes housing stability.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of General Services (DGS) to include a notation on identification cards indicating that the holder is a veteran, provided they submit proof of veteran status. If this option is offered, the DGS must allow applicants to consent to being contacted by executive agencies regarding state or federal veterans' benefits and prohibits sharing this information without such consent.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of General Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Veterans who are State employees, contractors, regulated lobbyists, media personnel, local government officials, or volunteers authorized to receive identification cards from the Department of General Services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Department of General Services can implement the veteran status notation and handle information transmission requirements using existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state revenues or local government operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of General Services (DGS) is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill. It issues the identification/security cards, manages the application process, provides the veteran status notation, and handles the transmission of veteran data to other executive agencies.

The bill explicitly requires certification of veteran status from this department and authorizes DGS to transmit contact information to 'appropriate executive agencies' (primarily DVMF) so they can reach out to veterans regarding State and federal benefits.

The bill allows the use of a DD Form 214 or other military documentation as proof of veteran status. The Adjutant General's office manages the state's historic military records and would be a key point of reference for verifying such documentation.

As the agency that manages the statewide personnel system, DBM is relevant because the primary holders of these identification cards are State employees, and the bill affects the administrative records and credentials of the State workforce.

The bill's definition of 'identification card' specifically includes 'regulated lobbyists,' a group overseen and regulated by the State Ethics Commission. This makes the bill relevant to a specific population under their jurisdiction.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill requires licensed funeral establishments, crematory operators, and reduction facilities to notify and transfer the unclaimed remains (including cremains, hydrolyzed remains, or soil remains) of veterans or their eligible dependents to the Maryland Department of Veterans and Military Families if a veterans service organization does not take possession of the remains within 10 days of notification. This process is intended to ensure the appropriate disposition of these remains in a State veterans' cemetery.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans and Military Families
qa_results.stakeholders: Veterans, eligible dependents of veterans, licensed funeral establishments, crematory operators, reduction facilities, and veterans service organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures and federal fund revenues for the Department of Veterans and Military Families may increase by an indeterminate but minimal amount starting in FY 2026. The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs provides a $978 plot allowance for veteran interments, which covers costs and perpetual care. However, the state is responsible for costs associated with burying dependents, which are estimated at approximately $5,000 annually. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This department is the primary agency impacted as it is specifically tasked with receiving unclaimed veteran remains and coordinating their final disposition and interment within state veterans' cemeteries.

The department's Office of Cemetery Oversight regulates crematory operators and reduction facilities under the Business Regulation Article, which this bill amends to establish new protocols for handling unclaimed remains of veterans.

The department oversees the State Board of Morticians and Funeral Directors, which regulates funeral establishments under the Health Occupations Article; this bill modifies that article to ensure consistent procedures for the disposition of unclaimed veteran remains.

The bill references the Forest Conservation Act regarding the transfer of soil remains from natural organic reduction to woodland owners, an area of environmental and land management managed by this department.
As the state’s central fiscal authority, this agency is impacted because the bill will result in an increase in general and federal fund expenditures for veteran burials and cemetery maintenance.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Maryland's health occupations boards to establish a process for including a notation of veteran status on an individual's license, certificate, registration, or public profile. It also allows applicants to consent to being contacted by state executive branch agencies regarding their eligibility for veterans' benefits and requires boards to share relevant applicant information with those agencies upon request.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and its health occupations boards
qa_results.stakeholders: Veterans seeking or holding health professional credentials and the 20 health occupations boards in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures for the Maryland Department of Health may increase minimally if health occupations boards choose to implement the veteran status notation process. Costs include one-time licensing software programming (estimated at $1,500 for the Board of Nursing) and potential administrative review, though these are expected to be absorbable within existing resources. No impact is expected on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the 20 health occupations boards housed within the Department of Health, authorizing them to create a veteran status notation on licenses and profiles. The fiscal note indicates that MDH special fund expenditures will be used for system upgrades and potential administrative costs associated with these boards.

The bill identifies the Department of Veterans & Military Families as a primary entity for certifying veteran status and assists the agency in its core mission of connecting veterans with state and federal benefits through authorized data sharing from health boards.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the legal advisor to the health occupations boards and would likely oversee the legal review of regulations and data-sharing agreements established under this bill.

The fiscal note identifies the need for upgrades to licensing and software systems to process veteran information and perform electronic data transmission to other executive agencies, which falls under the strategic and technical oversight of DoIT.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill renames the Chesapeake Conservation Corps Program to be the Thomas V. Mike Miller, Jr., Chesapeake Conservation and Climate Corps Program to honor the late Senate President's legacy and influence on the Chesapeake Bay.
qa_results.responsible_party: Chesapeake Bay Trust
qa_results.stakeholders: Young adults (ages 18-26), youth (ages 15-18), qualified community organizations, and Maryland residents in communities benefited by environmental restoration and climate mitigation projects.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect State or local finances. It is a renaming of an existing program that already has mandated funding streams, such as $375,000 annually from the Environmental Trust Fund and $1.5 million annually for climate projects as established by previous legislation.
